text: Rice University
Emergency Medical Services Protocols
Protocols valid as of August 2025
Dr. Cameron Decker Date
Rice EMS Medical Director

Patients, EMS providers, and EMS physicians supporting all aspects of EMS through clinical leadership all deserve the finest clinical treatment protocols available. This set of clinical guidelines has been written to guide Rice University EMS providers in offering quality prehospital care.

EMS professionals should never perform emergency medical care outside of their individual scope of practice established by professional medical training, certification/licensure, and medical oversight physician authorization. When encountering patient conditions requiring care unspecified in these clinical guidelines, seek appropriate direction from on-line medical control, always delivering care with prudence and reasonable regard for safety of the patient, peers, and the public.
General Rules for Following the Clinical Guidelines
Clinical guidelines may overlap with one another. In this situation, treat the most life- or limb- threatening problem first. If that is unknown, treat the most likely underlying problem first.
When the indicated treatment changes from one guideline to another guideline, do not administer more than the maximum total dose of a medication.

Some guidelines and drug dosage ranges are taught as absolutes. However, provider judgment based on individual patient conditions must also be used in determining appropriate patient care. For any case where deviation from the guideline seems like an appropriate course of action, medical command contact with a physician medical director should be made.

Any licensed medical personnel who orders procedures beyond the scope of these clinical guidelines must accompany the patient during transport to the hospital. Specific medical devices are occasionally utilized to illustrate one method of care performance in several protocols. Rice University EMS does NOT exclusively endorse these devices for use. Devices may change and/or be updated due to product availability. When possible, medication alternatives are indicated in the clinical guidelines in light of current and anticipated future medication supply shortages affecting EMS systems throughout the United States. It is the sincere hope that these clinical guidelines will guide Rice University EMS professionals in achieving the best clinical outcome possible for each and every patient receiving their dedicated care. ‌Authorization Level The following represents the patient care activities that are authorized to be performed by personnel as stated in the clinical guidelines. All BLS activities are authorized in a standing order to be used as needed. Authorization for ALS activities is indicated in the clinical guideline or procedure document for each intervention. The Medical Director(s), the EMS Director, and current Rice EMS advanced level preceptors have the authority to delegate beyond the guidelines for advanced level students as needed to directly supervise clinical skills performed within the scope of a provider’s certification and/or currently enrolled training level.  Calcium Chloride Amiodarone  Diltiazem Atropine  Sodium Bicarbonate Medical Director’s Signature: Date: 08/14/2025 ‌Infectious Disease Precaution Recommendations Rice University Emergency Medical Services Clinical Guidelines In the course of EMS care of a patient (from time of emergency services request through transport of the patient to the destination location), EMS professionals should be informed, aware, and proactive regarding practices that reduce their exposure to infectious diseases, with a goal of preventing transmission of those infectious diseases to and/or through EMS professionals. The following recommendations are general guidelines that will assist in reducing exposure to infectious diseases in the commission of EMS treatment of patients. Follow immunization recommendations from Centers for Disease Control Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices (ACIP) (e.g., Hepatitis B and Flu vaccinations) Always be prepared for isolation from body substances (blood, respiratory secretions, sputum, saliva, emesis, fecal matter). Wear examination gloves and eye protection during patient care activities. If patient conditions tolerate, reduce exposure of suspected infectious respiratory droplets by covering the patient’s nose and mouth in oxygen administration (e.g., non-rebreather mask) or with a face mask (e.g., surgical type face mask) if oxygen administration is not required. When providing airway assessment and management, maximize the functional distance between the patient’s nose and mouth and the EMS professional’s nose and mouth. The greater the possible distance, the lesser the risk of respiratory illness transmission. Wear appropriate body substance isolation (eye splash protection, mask over nose/mouth, gloves as previously noted, gown to protect personal uniform contamination) as patient suspected illness/injury may dictate. During treatment of the patient, avoid likely trajectories of bleeding, coughing, spitting, vomiting, defecating whenever possible. Exercise extremely diligent action when handling or around the handling of contaminated sharps (e.g., IV/IO needles, needle/syringe, glucometer lancets) and have appropriate sharps container readily present. Full sharps containers should be disposed of at the infectious waste collection area on campus, at the back dock of George R. Brown Hall. For all exposures, wash exposed area(s) as soon as possible with copious irrigation and/or antibacterial solution approved for that area(s) use. In the event of exposure, follow general principles as listed in Post-Exposure Prophylaxis Recommendations. Do not delay in reporting and seeking treatment for an infectious disease/body substance exposure of concern. Hand washing with soap and water should be done by all patient care providers after each call. Cleaning supplies are available in EMS responder vehicles, at RUPD, and at the Duncan EMS room. Patient care equipment should be cleaned after every call, with particular attention to frequently used items such as vital signs equipment, clipboards, and radios. Contact the Operations Lieutenant for any needed cleaning supplies. ‌Post-Exposure Prophylaxis Recommendations Rice University Emergency Medical Services Clinical Guidelines Preventing an exposure is always better than the “cure” for an exposure. Despite careful practices, EMS professionals can experience at least one concerning infectious disease exposure in a career. The following recommendations are general guidelines that can assist in post-exposure evaluation and PEP care: Wash exposed area(s) as soon as possible with copious irrigation and/or antibacterial solution approved for that area(s) use. Gather as much information about the exposure of concern as possible – what body substance (e.g., blood, saliva), what route of exposure, timing/amount of exposure, patient demographics, and any related infectious disease medical history of the patient (e.g., known HIV or Hepatitis C?). Do not delay in reporting and seeking treatment for an infectious disease/body substance exposure of concern. Regardless of time of day or day or week, seek direction from the appropriate EMS supervisor. Contact the InCharge present on the call, the EMS Captain or Senior Lieutenant, and/or the EMS Director immediately after the patient’s care can be transferred to other healthcare providers. Rice EMS Medical Command will be consulted for appropriate follow up care. Time to treatment (in hours) is of the essence to reduce transmission of infectious disease. Additional information on PEP care can be obtained at the following website: http://nccc.ucsf.edu/clinician-consultation/pep-post-exposure-prophylaxis/ Complete a First Report of Injury/Illness form, located on the Rice University Risk Management website. This form should be returned to the EMS Director. ‌Informed Patient Consent & Refusal Rice University Emergency Medical Services Clinical Guidelines Criteria Refusal = when competent patient refuses treatment and/or transport to advanced health care facility after being informed of suspected medical condition, type of treatment rendered and consequences and possible risks of treatment and refusal of treatment or transport Mental capacity of adult (>18 years old) patient. Capacity should be noted to include the following: Ability to communicate a choice concerning medical evaluation, treatment and/or transport Ability to understand relevant information about treatment/plan Ability to appreciate the significance of the information in this circumstance, by communicating understanding of risks and benefits Ability to use reasoning to select a choice (Pediatric) Mental competence of adult (>18 years old) caretaker as defined above General All personnel must have consent (either implied or informed) before treating a patient. Any adult of mental capacity or guardian may either consent to or refuse treatment/transport for themselves (adult) or patient for whom they are responsible (pediatric) Any police officer may order treatment or transportation of any prisoner in their custody Any patient may be transported against their will if the EMT has court order for patient to receive treatment or if the patient is in the custody of a law enforcement officer. Mentally incompetent patient or patients without the capacity to refuse Patients can be considered by either courts or by definition of policy may be treated under implied consent. If patient refuses to be treated/transported, RUPD may be notified to safely restrain patient. Refusal Any competent adult has the right to refuse treatment, even if that lack of treatment may result in death. Any patient refusing treatment or transport shall be informed of the possible consequences of that refusal and shall sign a refusal form. Individuals other than REMS personnel should sign as a witness the patient’s refusal, if possible. Any EMT who does not feel comfortable with a patient refusing treatment or transport because the EMT feels that the refusal may result in death or serious injury shall contact the EMS Director and/or an EMS Medical Director. Implied consent: the assumption that, in a true emergency where a patient who is unresponsive or unable to make a rational decision is at significant risk of death, disability, or deterioration of condition, that patient would agree to emergency treatment. Informed consent: consent for treatment that is given by a competent patient based on a full disclosure of possible risks and benefits. Prehospital Emergency Care, 10th Edition. Mistovich, Joseph J. Pearson Education, © 2014. All patients that REMS providers meet for an EMS call will be offered evaluation and transport to the emergency room. For patients who choose not to go to the emergency room by ambulance, a refusal form must be signed. This should be signed by the patient in most cases. Exceptions: If the patient is less than 18 years old, the patient’s parent or guardian may sign on their behalf if they are present on scene. If there is no parent or guardian on scene, the EMS provider should make a reasonable attempt to contact a parent or guardian on the phone to verify consent and refusal. If no parent or guardian is available on scene or on the phone, RUPD or a University official such as a College Master, Resident Assistant, or Athletics personnel such as a coach or trainer may be asked to sign on the minor’s behalf. In the case that no one is willing to sign on the minor’s behalf, Medical Command should be contacted for direction. A patient must be awake and alert, with a reasonable understanding of what the form states, to qualify to sign the refusal form. The EMS provider should review the information on the form with the patient, and then ask to check the patient understands what they are signing. Patients who are unable to understand the form, recall the information on the form, and/or who are physically unable to sign the form, should be reevaluated for competency. A patient who has a physical injury to an arm or hand that would make signing painful or difficult may choose to not sign the form. RUPD or a University Official should be requested to witness the patient’s acknowledgement of the refusal of ambulance transport. In the case of a patient who refuses to sign the form, RUPD or a University Official should be requested to respond to the scene to witness that EMS offered treatment and/or transport, but the patient refused these options, and refused to sign the form.

Patients should also be requested to sign the refusal form for refusal of specific interventions. A patient with neck pain may elect to not have a cervical collar applied, for instance, and should sign the form indicating they accept liability for this action.
‌Multiple Patient Scenes / Mass Casualty Events
Rice University Emergency Medical Services Clinical Guidelines
Definitions
A multiple patient scene involves multiple patients on scene, but not more patients than can be managed by the EMS resources available on campus.
A mass casualty event involves multiple patients than cannot be managed by the EMS resources available on campus.
A victim is a person involved in an incident that does not require or request medical attention, and no apparent injuries are identified.

A patient is a person involved in an incident that either requires or requests medical evaluation, treatment, or transport. A person with an obvious injury or ailment that refuses EMS care or evaluation is still considered a patient.

Incident command at these scenes will be assigned according to the National Incident Management System (NIMS) guidelines and a unified command team consisting of representatives of police, fire and EMS should be rapidly assigned and coordinated to ensure safe, efficient and effective operations.

Below please find a general outline of NIMS guidelines for mass casualty events, focused on the medical branch tasks. As a small agency. REMS will almost always need to call for additional assistance from Houston Fire Department for any large-scale emergency event. Familiarization with campus, and an ability to bridge communications between campus resources and Houston resources will likely be the most productive role that REMS staff can fill in a large-scale emergency event. See the REMS specific notes on the side of the page for practical tips.
Scene Tasks:
Initial Size-up Actions: Park initial arriving apparatus in safe location a short distance away from the incident.

Advise dispatch: Incident location (if different from initial dispatch) REMS – request additional assistance page from Dispatch. Incident type (transportation accident, fire, etc. if different from initial dispatch) The estimated number of patients. What additional resources are needed and how many are requested. Any hazardous conditions (weather, electrical, structural, toxic chemicals, etc.). Identify a “HOT ZONE” or ”Immediate Danger Zone,” if applicable Best route & access to scene (if appropriate) Staging area location (if staging indicated).
Check in with Incident Command staff to determine your ICS role. The medical treatment and transport of injured patients will normally be done through the position of Medical
Branch Director and subordinate positions headed by Group Supervisors. However, the Incident Commander will determine which positions, if any, they feel needs to be filled.
All information about the incident should be treated as Protected Health Information (number of patients, type of incident, hospital destinations)

For all large-scale incidents at Rice, the University’s Public Affairs Staff will serve as the Public Information Officer(s) and will release information about the incident to the press/public after consulting with Incident command staff. Specific Roles and Responsibilities:

Medical Branch Director Reports to the Operations Section Chief. Establishes the Triage, Treatment, and Transportation Areas (if indicated) and assigns individuals to the role of Group Supervisors (or Officers) for each area. Maintains adequate span of control within Medical Branch Establish appropriate EMS communications with appropriate response elements (i.e. Staging, logistics) REMS – forward important information on scene via the InCharge or EMS Director to the Command Staff. REMS – contact a medical director to advise of campus situation. Ask for their availability for future phone calls as needed throughout the incident. Establish and maintain communications with assigned Group Supervisors (Officers) Oversee the triage, treatment, transportation and accountability of patients created by the incident. Monitors the potential or actual effect of the incident on the existing medical infrastructure and communicates such with the Operations Section Chief Determines resource requirements to meet the medical needs of the incident and communicates needs to the Operations Section Chief or designated response element. Determines the need for specialized medical resources and processes requests for such elements through appropriate channels. Provides situation updates and reports to REMS – consider scope of event & weather. Will additional trash cans be needed? Drinking water? Contact campus resources via dispatch to request support in these areas the Operations Section Chief REMS – find a place to highlight and copy campus maps for EMS transport personnel, showing the most direct route to TMC hospitals from treatment area. REMS – Some large-scale Rice Events have preplanned MCI plans including staging, ingress/egress routes, and maps.

Group Supervisor (Officer): Establishes Area to perform assigned tasks Determine resource and staffing needs for Area of responsibility and communicates needs to Medical Branch Director Provides situational updates and reports to the Medical Branch Director Establish communications with the Medical Branch Directors and other needed response elements. Monitors safety and welfare of patients and assigned personnel Ensures patient tracking and accountability of injured patients in assigned area. Tasks during a Mass Casualty Incident: Triage Area:

The Initial triage of patient should begin where the incident occurred, unless a hazard or other situation indicates the scene is no longer safe. For scenes with hazards or safety concerns, a Casualty Collection Point should be established at a safe location nearby, outside of the designated “HOT ZONE.”
During the triage phase, no treatment is performed. In order to efficiently and effectively treat the casualties, you must ensure you know how many patients require treatment.

Every victim or patient within an incident will be tagged with a Texas EMS Wristband and logged into the Rice EMS patient tracking software, Pulsara®. Pulsara® will be used to track all individuals associated with the incident. A Texas EMS wristband will be placed on the patient’s extremity (Left arm preferred) The patient’s name, date of birth, and primary injury will be documented. The patient’s wristband number will be entered manually or scanned using the barcode scanner. The patient will be added to the incident in Pulsara® The patient will be triaged, and their acuity (“Condition”) will be logged into Pulsara®. No Color / Unmarked: A victim that DOES NOT require medical assistance Green: Patients with minor injuries who can walk and follow commands Yellow: Patients who are unable to walk, but are able to follow commands Red: Patients with life threatening injuries including altered mental status, RR ≥ 30, delayed Cap refill, or absent radial pulses Black: Patients who are deceased or have injuries that will not sustain life Link to START Triage Algorithm (Adult) and JUMPStart Algorithm (Pediatric) After the above steps have been completed, select CREATE at the bottom of the page and continue to the next patient. The CREATE button must be selected as soon as possible in order to allow others to begin documenting on the same patient channel.

Pulsara® will monitor and track the amount of patients and the number of patients in each category in real time. This information will be monitored by the Triage Group Supervisor (Officer), Medical Branch Director, and Command Staff. In the event of catastrophic failure of the communications network and Pulsara® cannot be utilized, a wristband will be attached to the patient’s extremity and their triage color will be written on their extremity, or a color-coded wristband or tape may be used.

Once established, each patient will be directed to the Treatment area based on their acuity. Ambulatory patients will be instructed to walk to the GREEN treatment area. Use discretion in allowing GREEN patients to assist in caring for critical patients while those more serious casualties are awaiting extrication to the treatment areas.

Repeat the triage process when possible and note changes in any patient’s condition. Perform a more detailed assessment, provide treatment, and update colored ribbon as appropriate while casualties are being extricated to the Treatment Area. If a victim becomes a patient, select their appropriate Condition (Green, Yellow, Red) on their Patient Channel in Pulsara® Treatment Area:

Establish a treatment area in consultation with the Medical Branch Director regarding location. Identify a large enough space to allow adequate room to triage, treat, and move casualties. Ensure the location promotes relative ease of ambulance loading and egress.

Request, assign, utilize, and oversee appropriate clinical personnel caring for patients. Assemble into crews of at least 2 personnel and use backboards and stair-chairs to package and extricate triaged casualties into the Red, Yellow, and Green treatment areas. Patients who have been marked deceased (Black) should not be moved into the treatment area. The Treatment Sector Officer may choose to have separate personnel perform treatment once inside the Treatment Area, if available. All persons involved in the incident triaged Green are to be kept in the Green Treatment Area until thoroughly REMS – what additional supplies will be needed? Consider utilizing non-sworn RUPD personnel for assistance in bringing additional equipment, such as cots or special event bags, to the treatment area. evaluated. These individuals will be released at an appropriate time by the Transport Group Supervisor (Officer). Depending on the circumstances, the Green casualties may be transported early or in large groups using alternative transport means. REMS – consider optimal staging & triage locations. Consider temperature- controlled locations, ideally two or three buildings away from incident.

During the treatment phase, more patient information should be collected and logged into Pulsara®. Use a Flowchart Note to document past medical history, current injuries / complaints, or any interventions (Medications or Skills) Add a Label to identify the patient’s affiliation (College, Visitor, Staff, or Unknown) Add in Vital signs (A minimum of a GCS, Respiratory Rate, and Pulse should be documented) Use the Contact Tab to document a patient’s phone number and email (if able and time permits) If available, Add in the patient's Rice ID, State ID, or DL into the Images tab. It is acceptable and encouraged to include images of the patient and their injuries into Pulsara®. Pulsara® is HIPPA compliant.

If a patient’s condition worsens (e.g. Yellow to Red; Green to Yellow) inside the Treatment Area, update the patient’s acuity within Pulsara® and move the patient to the appropriate location in the Treatment Area. Changing the patient's acuity in Pulsara will notify the Operations and Command Staff of the change in condition. Document the change in condition and time by adding a Flowchart Note into the patient’s Pulsara channel. Transportation Area:
The Transportation Area will require the coordinated effort of several people to coordinate with the Staging and Treatment Groups, and to assist with the tracking and movement of patients.
Outside agencies that utilize Pulsara® can obtain patient information by scanning the patient’s Texas EMS Wristband.

Establish a patient loading zone. Consider a close proximity to the treatment area and how the ambulances will approach and exit the area. Establish ambulance traffic routes that prevent ambulances from having to back-up to load patients or turn around to leave the area. This makes for safer and more efficient transport operations.

Consider establishing a secondary staging area. REMS – consider if non- ambulance transport would be of assistance for green category patients. Dispatch can contact Rice Transportation to request shuttle bus A staging area allows additional ambulances to wait outside of the patient loading zone to prevent a backlog or traffic jam. Work with the Staging Group Supervisor to ensure at least one ambulance is always in the loading zone.
Ensure vehicle operators stay with their ambulances to ensure as soon as patients are loaded, the ambulance leaves.

Communicate with Treatment Group Supervisor (Officer) when ambulances are available for transport. Each ambulance can only transport: One RED patient with one YELLOW or GREEN patient Two YELLOW patents

Pulsara® will be used to track where the patient is being transported and by which EMS agency and unit. One to two people should be assigned to this task. Rice EMS will: Select the transport destination for all patients being transported by HFD or City Ambulance. Other outside agencies who are using the Pulsara® app may select their own transport destination In the Chief Complaint box, the EMS Agency and Unit will be documented. Ex: HFD A16 or HCEC M91

Notify the Medical Branch Director when all patients have been cleared from the scene and transported. Maintain and secure records for the Medical Branch Director and secure the patient loading area. Staging Area

A Staging Group Supervisor (Officer) will oversee the establishment and operations of the staging area. The staging area may not be required for all incidents. A staging area is a secondary location to temporarily store (“stage”) additional resources until they are needed Staging area should be large enough to contain numerous ambulances, fire apparatus, or transportation assets such as buses and vans. The staging area should be far enough from the Treatment Area that units are not prevented from leaving the area or creating a traffic jam, but close enough to loading zone to allow for short drive times.
Select and communicate a desired travel route for resources assigned to the Staging Area. This route should allow for easy access but should take units away from the impacted area.
The Staging Group Supervisor (Officer) should coordinate an orderly arrangement of arriving apparatus to allow for ease of ambulance ingress to the transport loading zone.

The Staging Group Supervisor (Officer) or the officer’s designee should maintain a log of available resources in the staging area and communicate with the Medical Branch Director the number of resource and if any more are required or have not yet arrived.

The Staging Sector Officer or the officer’s designee should assure ambulance or specialty transport crews stay with their assigned vehicles to ensure rapid availability of the asset when requested at the transport loading zone.

Delivering equipment needed in the treatment sector that is requested from staging in an organized manor with the minimum number of personnel leaving the staging area to deliver this equipment. Alternatively, all the requested equipment may be sent to the treatment area on one designated vehicle.

Assign and deploy transportation assets to the loading zone(s) at the request of the Medical Branch Director or the Transportation Group Supervisor depending on the established communication pathways. Mass Casualty Medical Communications

Medical communications during a mass casualty incident, like all other incident communications, are of critical importance and often will determine the level of effectiveness and success of the operation. Basic communication principals should be used during an incident. Use of interoperable radio channels so all agencies are able to communicate. Following the overall incident communications plan established by the Incident Commander. Establishing assigned, clear, and understood lines of communications, who will communicate with whom, for what reason, and by what method. Use of multiple and redundant means of communications including, but limited to, radio, data, phone, runners, face-to-face, and even hand signals. Preparation for communications failure and immediately switching over to one of the established redundant communication means. Ensuring communications sent receive a response of some manner to ensure the loop has been closed.

Medical communications from the scene of an MCI, depending on complexity and command structure, often involves up to three different levels of communications: Communications (internal) with other Incident Command System elements Operations Section Chief or designee(s) Unified Command medical representatives Logistics, Planning, Admin/Finance if appropriate Communications (internal) within the scene medical response infrastructure (Triage, Treatment, Transportation, Staging Group Supervisors) Communications (external) with local, county, or regional medical coordination entities

After assigning support positions, one of the first activities of the Medical Branch Director should be to establish redundant communications pathways within the ICS structure, subordinate Group Supervisors (Officers), and other medical response elements by: Obtaining the ICS Communication Plan (Incident Channels, etc.). Determine reporting lines and redundant means of communication with Group Supervisors (Officers). Establishing and communicating manner for all communications acknowledgments. Establish communications via radio, e-mail, or phone with outside medical coordination entities Advise the ICS infrastructure of communication pathways for incorporation into the updated ICS communication plan. Harris County Mutual Aid Channels

During large-scale events involving multiple agencies, the Incident Command Team may direct you to move to a designated regional mutual aid channel. These channels are referred to as “Harris County Mutual Aid” followed by a number. (Ex: HCMA #2) Change the Zone: Harris County Mutual Aid channels are on “Zone 76”. On your radio, select ZONE and then navigate to “Zone 76” APX 7000 (Old Radios) APX N70 (New Radios) Change the Channel: Rotate the dial to the appropriate channel number. The ICS 205 Form (Radio Comms) will include a Zone and Channel number for any radio channels being utilized during an incident. Use this guide to find the channels. MCI Equipment

Rice EMS is currently carrying the Thomas Triage Packs One pack can be found in the REMS Tahoe and the REMS Expedition The packs include six colors of plastic ribbon. Each patient should receive a 6–8- inch ribbon with the appropriate color after being triaged. Patient categories are: Immediate (RED) Delayed (YELLOW) Minor (GREEN) – “Walking Wounded” Deceased or Expectant (BLACK) The pack also contains two additional color tape rolls for hazards: Orange – a contaminated patient Blue – patients have been treated with an antidote Patients will still need to be logged into Pulsara. This will not replace the online patient tracking.
Revised 07.10.2023
Patient Destination Determination
‌Rice University Emergency Medical Services Clinical Guidelines

Rice EMS is a First Responder Agency and does not provide transportation for patients. All patients are offered ambulance transportation, and for those who refuse ambulance transportation alternative destinations may be appropriate. As a general guideline:

Undergraduate patients with a medical complaint such as flu, fever, cough/cold symptoms, abdominal pain, allergies/asthma, etc., may be seen at the Rice Health Services if appointments are available. Call Health Services (x4966) to ask about appointment availability.

Urgent Care centers, such as AFC, can see patients with similar medical complaints to Rice Health Services. Any patient with a more serious medical complaint, or requiring specialist care and/or inpatient care, should be seen at an emergency department.
University employees with minor work-related injuries can be seen at Nova Clinic with workers compensation. Risk Management should be notified if a patient seeks care at Nova Clinic.

Off campus stand-alone emergency centers, such as Methodist Emergency Care Center, are equipped to handle any medical emergency. Any patient requiring specialist care, and/or inpatient care, would have to be transferred to another facility.

Texas Medical Center has multiple hospital-based emergency departments. Ben Taub, Memorial Hermann, and Texas Children’s Hospital are Level I trauma centers, and can care for the most serious medical emergencies or traumatic injuries. Methodist Hospital and St. Luke’s Hospital are also neighboring emergency rooms capable of handling medical and traumatic injuries. Specialty Care Some patients may have a specific condition or injury that would be best treated at certain facilities. Patients with:
Burn: Memorial Hermann is best equipped for any moderate or serious burns
Chemical exposure: Memorial Hermann is best equipped for chemical exposure
Dental emergency: generally, should be seen at a hospital-based emergency department
Eye injury/condition: generally, should be seen at a hospital-based emergency department
Psychiatric emergency: Ben Taub and Methodist Hospital are able to evaluate patients in the emergency department, and also offer inpatient psychiatric care

Sexual assault: any emergency department in the TMC can provide specially trained nursing staff to care for patients who have experienced sexual assault. Ben Taub has Sexual Assault Nurse Examiners (SANE) available at all times Pediatric patients with suspected sexual assault should be evaluated at Texas Children’s Hospital or Memorial Hermann. Rice EMS does not endorse any particular health care facility. ‌Rice University Emergency Medical Services Clinical Guidelines Medical Assessment & Treatment ‌Medical General Assessment: Adult and Pediatric Rice University Emergency Medical Services Clinical Guidelines Treatment Priorities
Assessment SCENE SAFETY PROTECTIVE EQUIPMENT Primary Survey Secondary Survey (when appropriate)
Primary Survey Care Initiate cardiopulmonary resuscitation if indicated Open airway Support oxygenation/ventilation Support circulation: dysrhythmia care? rate control? hypotension care?
Ongoing Care Reassess all primary care Support oxygenation/ventilation Vascular access Secondary Survey (if able) Keep patient warm/avoid hypothermia
Appropriate Destination General Approach the assessment of medical (non-trauma) patients in A-B-C order. Airway
Evaluate the patency and mechanics of the airway. Is the patient able to oxygenate and ventilate?
Rapid intervention may be required during the assessment phase if airway patency and protection is compromised. Breathing
Expose the chest as required to accurately assess the mechanics of respiration (considering patient privacy/modesty if in public location).
Note the rate, depth, and pattern of respirations and any degree of respiratory distress or effort.
Auscultate breath sounds bilaterally.

Liberally obtain pulse oximetry readings and in patients with respiratory difficulties, waveform capnography readings (if equipped). **Waveform capnography is mandatory if an advanced airway is in place. Circulation
The adequacy of a patient’s circulation is best assessed first by evaluating their level of consciousness and mental status.
Next assess the location, rate, and character of the pulse.
Then check a blood pressure, preferably manually for at least the first reading.
Apply the cardiac monitor (if equipped) liberally. Special Considerations
Cardiac Arrest is an exception to the above order. Aggressively initiate chest compressions and search for shockable rhythms at the appropriate intervals per the Cardiac Arrest Protocol.

Many treatment decisions regarding airway management involve calculating the adult patient’s Glasgow Coma Scale score using the following table: Points Best eye Best verbal Best motor 6 --- --- Obeys verbal orders 5 --- Oriented, conversational Localizes to pain 4 Spontaneously Disoriented, conversational Withdraws to pain 3 To command Inappropriate words Flexion (decorticate) 2 To pain Inappropriate sounds Extension (decerebrate) 1 No response No response No response

After addressing the A-B-C order in most medical patients, including evaluating and addressing any life-threatening conditions, minimize scene time and initiate steps needed for transport to an appropriate emergency department in any setting of a time-sensitive medical condition.

Complete a head-to-toe assessment of the patient if the patient is relatively medically stable. Obtain relevant history of past and current medical problems, medications, allergies, and physicians/hospitals used in care plans to help guide further assessment.

Reassess patients frequently, typically at least every 10 minutes, and more often if critical illness is discovered and being treated. In the situations of an unstable patient, vital signs should be assessed every 5 minutes, especially if hemodynamic changes are occurring.
Assess and treat per symptom or illness specific protocols that follow in this protocol set. Pediatric Assessment Considerations

Pediatric respiratory distress may look just like adult respiratory distress, presenting with: slowing respirations, cyanosis, accessory muscle use, paleness, nasal flaring, lethargy/listlessness, retractions – intercostal or subcostal, irritability, tachypnea, stridor, mottling, grunting

Vital signs vary with age. In general, the younger the patient, the faster the respiratory rate, the faster the heart rate, and the lower the blood pressure: The average normal systolic BP can also be estimated using: 80 + (2 x age) in years. Lower limits of normal systolic BP can also be estimated using: 70 + (2 x age) in years.

Consider abdominal aortic aneurysm for patients with pain described as tearing or shredding ‌Allergic Reaction & Anaphylaxis Rice University Emergency Medical Services Clinical Guidelines Acute Urticarial Reactions may develop in patients who have been exposed to an environmental trigger, medication, or food. The reaction may be mild, including symptoms of:
Hives, rash, or an itch
Localized peripheral edema and redness Credit: https://dermnetnz.org/topics/urticaria-an-overview The reaction may progress to include systemic symptoms (i.e. anaphylaxis), including:
Dyspnea, wheezing, or other respiratory complaints
Nausea and/or vomiting
Generalized edema Anaphylaxis should be suspected in patients who experience symptoms of two or more body systems with any combination of symptoms, and/or hypotension.

Be sure to distinguish between allergic/urticarial reaction and anaphylaxis/anaphylactic shock. As stated above, anaphylaxis involves more than one body system and presents with symptoms like edema, respiratory distress, nausea/vomiting in addition to urticaria/itching. If there is a problem with airway, breathing, or circulation, anaphylaxis is likely.
Anaphylactic shock is accompanied by hypotension.

For anaphylaxis, the priority is rapid Epinephrine administration. A thorough comprehensive physical exam should be performed for any patient with suspected allergic reaction and/or anaphylaxis, including a thorough assessment of the skin to assess for hives and/or rash; oropharynx, lips, and face for any edema; and lung sounds. Treatment and Interventions: EMT *** For Anaphylaxis Only: Pediatric Advanced EMT *** For acute urticarial reaction: *** For anaphylaxis: Remove the patient from allergen / environment CABC’s Oxygen, as needed, to ensure adequate oxygenation and ventilation Assist patients with their own albuterol inhaler (when applicable) General supportive care Assist patients with their Epi-Pen® auto-injector in the anterior/lateral thigh OR Contact medical command for permission, then administer epinephrine from vial Adult dose: Epinephrine 1:1000, 0.3mg If the patient has dyspnea with wheezing, administer Albuterol 5 mg via nebulizer Contact medical command for subsequent doses. Assist patients with their Epi-Pen Jr® auto-injector in the anterior/lateral thigh OR Contact medical command for permission, then administer epinephrine from vial Pediatric dose: Epinephrine 1:1000, 0.15mg If the patient has dyspnea with wheezing, administer Albuterol 2.5 mg via nebulizer Contact medical command for subsequent doses. Includes EMT scope as above Assess oxygenation & ventilation; consider SPO2 and EtCO2 waveform capnography. Consider placement of a supraglottic airway if indicated AND only if BVM ventilations are ineffective. Loratadine (Claritin) 10 mg PO Epinephrine 1:1000, 0.01mg/kg (max dose 0.5 mg) administered IM in the anterior/lateral thigh. Medical command consult required if the diagnosis is in question. BP < 90 mmHg OR with symptoms of hypotension and no signs of volume overload (rales on lung auscultation or significant lower extremity edema). Repeat up to 2 Liters of Normal Saline if Sys. BP remains < 100 mmHg and no signs of pulmonary edema. Diphenhydramine 50 mg IV IM administration may be considered if unable to obtain IV access. Methylprednisolone 1 mg/kg IV (max 125) Pediatric *** For acute allergic reaction: *** For anaphylaxis: Paramedic *** For anaphylaxis: Pediatric anaphylaxis treatment: If the patient has dyspnea with wheezing, administer Albuterol 5 mg via nebulizer. Medical command should be consulted for additional doses. BP > (70 + 2x age in years) mmHg IV Normal Saline 20mL/kg bolus if Sys. BP < (70 + 2x age in years) mmHg OR with symptoms of hypotension and no signs of volume overload. Use precaution and situational awareness to ensure that REMS personnel do not become contaminated with the allergen.
Epi-Pen© or Epi-Pen Jr.© is administered to the lateral surface of the patient’s thigh, midway between the hip and knee.
Properly dispose of sharps to minimize risk of exposure.
Continuous monitoring of the patient is preferred, and treatments (O2, fluids) should be titrated to patient’s condition.

Advanced EMT continued Hypoglycemia (BGL < 50 mg/dL): 10% Dextrose (D10) 5 mL/kg IV/IO bolus up to 250 mL - OR - Patients > 25 kg: 1mL/kg D50 IV/IO push up to 50mL Glucagon 1 mg IM if vascular access cannot be obtained Pediatric < 25 kg D25 2 mL/kg IV push up to 50 mL – OR - D10 5mL/kg IV/IO bolus up to 250mL Glucagon 0.5 mg IM if vascular access cannot be obtained Toxins or Drug Overdose – use with suspected narcotic or opiate overdose with apnea or ineffective / agonal breathing: Adult: Naloxone 0.4 mg IVP/IOP/IN/IM, may repeat every 5 minutes up to a total of 4 mg If available, consider using Single Use 4mg Nasal Narcan Spray Pediatric: Naloxone 0.1 mg/kg (Max Dose 0.4 mg) IVP/IOP/IN/IM, may repeat every 5 minutes up to a total of 4 mg Use Naloxone to restore effective breathing; avoid excessive dosing to prevent withdrawal
25% Dextrose solution (D25) is made by diluting 50% Dextrose (D50) with equal parts normal saline. 50mL of D50 should be mixed with 50mL of Normal saline to make D25.

Naloxone (Narcan) is intended to restore an adequate breathing pattern and is not designed to be used to “wake up” an overdose patient. Administer Naloxone in low doses until a normal breathing pattern is restored. Excited Delirium Syndrome

Excited delirium is defined as a state of extreme mental and psychological excitement, usually associated with chronic or illicit drug use, characterized by symptoms such as: Exceptional agitation, hyperactivity, and exceptional strength Hyperthermia Hostility, aggression, and paranoia

Patients are often found naked or stripping clothes to cool down due to extreme hyperthermia, often above 102°F. If safe to do so, actively cool the patient with icepacks and evaporative cooling, making sure not to induce hypothermia
Law Enforcement should be notified immediately in cases of suspected Excited Delirium. REMS members should remain a safe distance away from the patient until law enforcement has arrived.
Patients often die suddenly, immediately following cessation of resistance; therefore, don’t mistake a sudden unexpected calm for compliance

Transport as quickly and safely as possible. Behavioral Emergency Rice University Emergency Medical Services Clinical Guidelines Criteria Unusual behavior/activity Possible aggression Altered Mental Status Treatment EMT AEMT Scene safety and police involvement Manage CABCs Obtain vital signs (if this can be done safely) Determine Blood Glucose Level ‌Apply cardiac monitor (if this can be done safely) Oxygen Administration as appropriate Consider coaching breathing Do not leave patient unattended Monitor EtCO2 and Waveform Capnography Consider IV access and NS administration ADULT: IV NS TKO if SBP ≥ 100 mmHg without hypotensive symptoms IV NS 250 mL bolus if SBP < 100 mmHg with hypotensive symptoms and no signs of pulmonary edema Repeat up to 2 L NS if SBP remains < 100 mmHg with hypotensive symptoms and no signs of pulmonary edema PEDIATRIC: IV NS TKO if SBP ≥ (70+2x age in years) mmHg without hypotensive symptoms IV NS 20 mL/kg bolus if SBP < (70 + 2x age in years) mmHg with hypotensive symptoms and no signs of pulmonary edema Repeat up to 60 mL/kg if SBP remains < (70 + 2x age in years) mmHg with hypotensive symptoms and no signs of pulmonary edema General Treatment Priorities Provider safety Safety of police/rescue personnel Safety of patient Observe for uncontrolled movement or agitation that may interfere with medical interventions Employ alternative methods to avoid physically restraining patient Restrain patient if patient becomes a danger to themselves or environment, or as necessary to perform needed interventions Considerations Utilize counseling resources for assistance. Rice Counseling 24/7 – (713)-348-3311 Be wary of excited delirium Listen to the patient, be honest and ask pertinent questions: Are you considering harming yourself or others? Do you have a plan for hurting someone, or yourself? Do you already have the means? Have you ever been, or are you currently, under the care of a psychiatrist for your mental health? Do you take any medications for your mental health, or are you prescribed any medications that you’re not currently taking? Are you hearing voices that other people are not able to hear? Are the voices encouraging you to take any action, such as hurting yourself or others? Are you able to see things or people that others around you aren’t able to see? Are these people encouraging you to take any action, such as hurting yourself or others? Utilize QPR for suicidal patients: Question, Persuade, Refer Cardiac Arrest Rice University Emergency Medical Services Clinical Guidelines Criteria:

Patients who are unresponsive, Apneic or agonal gaps, and pulseless Treatment EMT Advanced EMT Apply the AED If estimated downtime is > 4 min, do 2 min of CPR before applying AED Perform high-quality CPR: Uninterrupted compressions at a rate of 100 – 120 per minute All full chest recoil between chest compressions Switch compressor every 2 minutes Pause compressions only for AED analysis and shocking ‌Immediately resume compressions after an AED shocks, or after AED advises no shock Give 1 breath every 5 to 6 seconds, DO NOT pause compressions during breaths Consider cardiac monitor for defibrillation if available Adult: 1st: 200J, 2nd: 300J, 3rd and subsequent shocks: 360J Pediatric: 2 J/kg, 4 J/kg, then subsequent ≥ 4 J/kg (Max: 10 J/kg or 360 J) Place Air-Q without pause in chest compressions Adult: 1 breath every 5 to 6 seconds (10-12/min) if advanced airway Pediatric: 1 breath every 2 to 3 seconds (20-30/min) if advanced airway Monitor EtCO2 and Waveform Capnography If EtCO2 is less than 10 mmHg, attempt to improve chest compressions Obtain IV / IO access Administer Epinephrine 1:10,000 every 3 to 5 minutes while patient is still pulseless Adult: 1 mg IV/IO Pediatric: 0.01 mg/kg IV/IO (Max Dose: 1 mg) Assess for and treat underlying etiology Hypovolemia suspected: Adult: 1 L Normal Saline IV/IO bolus if no signs of pulmonary edema Pediatric: 20 mL/kg Normal Saline IV/IO bolus if no signs of pulmonary edema Hypoglycemia suspected (BGL < 60 mg/dL): 10% Dextrose (D10) 5 mL/kg IV/IO bolus up to 250 mL - OR – Patients > 25 kg: D50 1mL/kg IV/IO push up to 50mL Pediatric < 25 kg D25 2 mL/kg IV push up to 50 mL – OR – D10 5mL/kg IV/IO bolus up to 250mL Advanced EMT continued Paramedic Narcotic or opiate overdose suspected: Adult: Naloxone 0.4 mg IVP/IOP/IN/IM, may repeat every 5 minutes up to a total of 4mg If available, consider using Single Use 4mg Nasal Narcan Spray Pediatric: Naloxone 0.1 mg/kg (Max Dose: 0.4mg) IVP/IOP/IN/IM, may repeat every 5 minutes up to a total of 4 mg Administer Epinephrine 1:10,000 every 3 to 5 minutes while patient is still pulseless Adult: 1 mg IV/IO Pediatric: 0.01 mg/kg IV/IO (Max Dose: 1 mg) Specific rhythm management Asystole / Pulseless Electrical Activity Administer Epinephrine 1:10,000 every 3 to 5 minutes Adult: 1 mg IV/IO Pediatric: 0.01 mg/kg IV/IO (Max Dose: 1 mg) Ventricular Fibrillation and Pulseless Ventricular Tachycardia Administer Epinephrine 1:10,000 every 3 to 5 minutes Adult: 1 mg IV/IO Pediatric: 0.01 mg/kg IV/IO (Max Dose: 1 mg) Administer Amiodarone IV/IO Adult: 1st Dose of 300 mg then 2nd Dose of 150 mg after 5 min Pediatric: Single dose of 5 mg/kg If ROSC is obtained after Amiodarone, consider: Adult: Amiodarone 150 mg IV/IO over 10 minutes Pediatric: Medical Control consult required Assess for, and treat, underlying reversible causes of cardiac arrest Hyperkalemia: Calcium Chloride 10mg/kg IV/IO (Max Dose 1 Gram) Sodium Bicarbonate 1 mEq/kg IV/IO (Max Dose 50 mEq) Pre-existing acidosis: Sodium Bicarbonate 1 mEq/kg IV/IO (Max Dose 50 mEq) Tricyclic antidepressant overdose: Sodium Bicarbonate 1 mEq/kg IV/IO (Max Dose 50 mEq) Beta blocker overdose: Adult: Glucagon 1 mg IV/IO Pediatric: Glucagon 0.03 mg/kg IV/IO (Max Dose 1 mg) Calcium channel blocker overdose: Calcium Chloride 10mg/kg IV/IO (Max Dose 1 Gram) General:

High quality CPR guidelines The chest compression rate should be 100-120 per minute If available, utilize a metronome. For the LP 15, push the CPR button on the right side of the screen Switch compressors every 100 compressions or 2 minutes

Prioritize minimal pauses in compressions Only pause compressions during AED analysis and shocking Limit compression pauses to under 10 seconds Do not pause for placement of an advanced airway Do not pause for breaths, even without an advanced airway
Consider reversible causes of cardiac arrest (Hs & Ts) Withholding Resuscitation

If a patient has a valid “Out of Hospital Do Not Resuscitate” or other Advanced Directive orders: All EMTs, Advanced EMTs, and Paramedics shall follow physician’s written “Do Not Resuscitate (DNR)” order, Texas DNR Consent form, or Advanced Health Care Directive accompanied by written statement from physicians Requests can only be honored by bystanders if accompanied by appropriate documentation If there is any doubt, begin CPR and immediately contact medical control

CPR should not be initiated, or be continued if initiated, by EMTs, Advanced EMTs, or Paramedics in the event of obvious death. Obvious death is defined as: Regardless of the cause of cardiac arrest No pulse AND no spontaneous respirations AND pupils fixed (unreactive to light) AND one or more of the following: Rigor mortis Decapitation Decomposition Blunt traumatic cardiac arrest No pulse AND no spontaneous respirations AND no shockable rhythm AND no organized ECG activity (Asystole) Penetrating traumatic cardiac arrest No pulse AND no spontaneous respirations AND pupils fixed (unreactive to light) AND no spontaneous movement AND no organized ECG activity (Asystole)

In any of the above-mentioned and confirmed situations, cease or withhold BVM ventilations, placement of an advanced airway, defibrillation, CPR, and any medication administration as applicable to cardiopulmonary resuscitation.
Unless obvious death criteria met as outlined above, CPR and other resuscitative efforts should be initiated and delivered to promote the best chance of patient survival.

Rice University Emergency Medical Services Clinical Guidelines
In general, heart rate outside of normal parameters Tachycardia: HR > 150 bpm in adults OR HR > 180 bpm in non-febrile pediatrics Bradycardia: HR < 60 bpm

May or may not have associated symptoms Treatment EMT ‌AEMT Paramedic Obtain vital signs (apply cardiac monitor) Oxygen Administration as appropriate ECG monitoring (see Cardiac Monitor Operation) Obtain 12-lead ECG Obtain IV access If myocardial infarction suspected, consider: ADULT: ASA 324 mg PO, chewed by patient Do not give if ASA was taken within 1 hour or otherwise contraindicated Sinus Bradycardia / 1° AV Block / 2° AV Block, Type I (Wenckebach) Asymptomatic Monitor rhythm ADULT: symptomatic, SBP < 100 mmHG, ACS suspected Treat per ACS guideline, avoid Atropine unless HR < 40 bpm ADULT: symptomatic, SBP < 100 mmHG, NO ACS suspected Atropine 0.5 mg IV/IO, repeat every 5 minutes (max 3 mg) PEDIATRIC: symptomatic, SBP < (70 + 2x age) mmHG Epinephrine [1:10,000] 0.01 mg/kg IV/IO, may repeat once If unresponsive to Epinephrine: Atropine 0.02 mg/kg IV/IO (min 0.1 mg, max 0.5 mg), may repeat once Bradycardia 2° AV Block, Type II (Classic) / 3° AV Block (Complete) Asymptomatic Monitor rhythm Place pacing pads per Cardiac Pacing ADULT: symptomatic, ACS suspected Treat per ACS guideline Use Cardiac Pacing at 60 bpm instead of Atropine ADULT: symptomatic, NO ACS suspected Use Cardiac Pacing at 60 bpm instead of Atropine PEDIATRIC: symptomatic Place pacing pads per Cardiac Pacing Consult medical command for orders Stable Atrial Fibrillation / Flutter If patient < 70 years old: Diltiazem 0.25 mg/kg (max 25 mg) SLOW IV over 2 mins If patient ≥ 70 years old: Diltiazem 0.25 mg/kg (max 10 mg) SLOW IV over 2 mins Stable Supraventricular Tachycardia Valsalva maneuver If not resolved: Adenosine 12 mg rapid IVP, may repeat once Stable Monomorphic V-Tach / Wide-Complex Unknown Origin Amiodarone 150 mg very slow IV over 10 mins Unstable Tachycardia (All Types) Begin Synchronized Cardioversion, 100 J – 200 J – 300 J – 360 J After resolution of unstable V-Tach, consider: Amiodarone 150 mg very slow IV over 10 mins to prevent arrhythmia reoccurrence General
In this reference, unstable is defined as: ADULT: SBP < 100 PEDIATRIC: SBP < (70 + 2x age) AND at least one of the following symptoms: Dyspnea Chest pain Weakness AMS Hypoxemia Pulmonary edema
Always check for a pulse with any rhythm change
2° AV Block Type I refers to Wenckebach phenomenon Progressive prolongation of the PR length until a dropped QRS complex occurs

2° AV Block Type II refers to the Classic or Mobitz phenomenon PR length remains constant Regular pattern of dropped QRS complexes (e.g., every third QRS is not observed) Chest Pain of Unknown Etiology Rice University Emergency Medical Services Clinical Guidelines Criteria
Patients complaining of non-traumatic chest pain.
Any pain of the chest/back/shoulder/neck/jaw/arm/epigastrium, SOB, nausea, diaphoresis, syncope, and/or generalized weakness/fatigue may be indicative of myocardial ischemia.
Atypical presentations are often seen in certain patient populations, including females, diabetics, the elderly, and those with comorbidities.

COVID-19 symptoms may include a wide range of symptoms, ranging from one or two mild symptoms to severe illness. This may include:
Fever or chills
Shortness of breath or diﬃculty breathing
Muscle or body aches
‌New loss of taste or smell
Sore throat
Congestion or runny nose
Nausea or vomiting

Diarrhea Appropriate PPE must be worn for every COVID positive patient or suspected COVID patient. For any patient complaining of the symptoms listed above, providers are required to don an N-95 respirator, eye protection, gown, and gloves. The patient should be given a surgical mask. The donning order for PPE is as follows:
N-95 respirator
Eye protection
Gloves The doﬃng order for PPE is as follows:
Eye protection

N-95 respirator To remove gloves safely, pinch the glove on one hand at the wrist with the foreﬁnger and thumb of the other hand. Pull the glove oﬀ while turning it inside out. Hold the removed glove in the gloved hand, slide the foreﬁnger of the non-gloved hand inside the wrist of the other glove, and pull it oﬀ. Hand washing with soap and water should be done by all providers after each call. Contact with the patient should be minimized when possible. See Isolation Housing SOP for response procedures. Equipment should also be placed in the hallway at a safe distance away from the patient. Treatment should be limited to interview and destination planning as much as possible. If additional care is needed, the steps below can be considered for patients in moderate to severe distress. Treatment EMT AEMT General supportive care Manage ABCs Assess lung sounds and temperature Oxygen Administration and BVM ventilations as appropriate Obtain a detailed history of the patient’s travel, contact with others, and possible exposure Monitor EtCO2 and Waveform Capnography Consider obtaining 12-Lead ECG Consider Supraglottic Airway if indicated and only if BVM ventilations are ineffective Consider IV access and NS administration ADULT: IV NS 250 mL bolus if SBP < 100 mmHg with hypotensive symptoms and no signs of pulmonary edema PEDIATRIC: IV NS 20 mL/kg bolus if SBP < (70 + 2x age in years) mmHg with hypotensive symptoms and no signs of pulmonary edema General Properly clean all equipment, including radios, pagers, and clipboards, using bleach wipes. Equipment should be cleaned away from the patient’s room. Dyspnea of Unknown Etiology Rice University Emergency Medical Services Clinical Guidelines Criteria Dyspnea Treatment EMT AEMT Obtain vital signs (apply cardiac monitor) Oxygen Administration and BVM ventilations as appropriate Assist patient with their own albuterol inhaler or nebulizer (when applicable) OR: ADULT or PEDIATRIC ≥ 15 kg: Albuterol 5 mg via nebulizer (see Nebulization Therapy) May repeat twice, every 10 minutes, if no patient relief AND HR does not increase by ≥ 20 bpm ‌PEDIATRIC < 15 kg: Albuterol 2.5 mg via nebulizer (see Nebulization Therapy) Medical command consult required for additional doses Monitor EtCO2 and Waveform Capnography Consider Supraglottic Airway if indicated and only if BVM ventilations are ineffective Obtain 12-lead ECG Consider IV access and NS administration ADULT: IV NS TKO if SBP ≥ 100 mmHg without hypotensive symptoms IV NS 250 mL bolus if SBP < 100 mmHg with hypotensive symptoms and no signs of pulmonary edema Repeat up to 2 L NS if SBP remains < 100 mmHg with hypotensive symptoms and no signs of pulmonary edema PEDIATRIC: IV NS TKO if SBP ≥ (70+2x age in years) mmHg without hypotensive symptoms IV NS 20 mL/kg bolus if SBP < (70 + 2x age in years) mmHg with hypotensive symptoms and no signs of pulmonary edema General Albuterol is indicated for suspected bronchospasm and/or reactive airway disease. Signs may include wheezing, poor air movement with labored effort, and/or diminished lung sounds. Patients with congestive heart failure (CHF) may present with wheezing but the problem is from cardiac etiology. Albuterol will not help and should not be administered in this case. Environmental: Cold Illness Rice University Emergency Medical Services Clinical Guidelines Criteria Although Houston has a generally temperate climate, cold illness/injury should remain a concern for patients found out of doors in the winter months. Hypothermia can occur with brief exposure to cold weather, and with prolonged exposure in ambient temperatures as high as 50 – 60℉, particularly if the patient is wet from rain or other environmental conditions. Treatment EMT AEMT Paramedic Manage CABCs Remove patient from cold environment and remove wet/restrictive clothing ‌Apply heat packs to groin, neck, axilla Cover patient with blankets to extent clinically possible Obtain vital signs (apply cardiac monitor) Oxygen Administration as appropriate If frostbite, apply loose sterile dressings and splint involved extremities Monitor EtCO2 and Waveform Capnography Consider Supraglottic Airway if indicated and only if BVM ventilations are ineffective Obtain IV access and consider NS administration (use warmed NS if available) ADULT: IV NS 500 mL if no signs of pulmonary edema Repeat up to 2 L NS if: Temperature remains < 30℃ (86℉) and/or Altered Mental Status remains and/or SBP remains < 100 mmHg if no signs of pulmonary edema PEDIATRIC: IV NS 20 mL/kg bolus if no signs of pulmonary edema Repeat up to 60 mL/kg if: Temperature < 30℃ (86℉) and/or Altered Mental Status and/or SBP < (70 + 2x age in years) mmHg if no signs of pulmonary edema ECG monitoring (see Cardiac Monitor Operation) Environmental: Heat Illness Rice University Emergency Medical Services Clinical Guidelines Criteria Heat illness should be considered for patients engaged in activity outdoors in high humidity, high temperatures, and subsequently high heat index. Heat illness may be the primary cause of the emergency or may contribute to or develop with other medical or traumatic conditions. Heat illness may progress quickly to a life-threatening condition. Stages of heat illness include: Heat Cramps: Minor muscle cramps usually in the legs and abdominal wall. Temperature is normal. Heat Exhaustion: May include weakness, vertigo, nausea/vomiting, tachycardia, profuse sweating, and/or syncope. Temperature may be normal or 1 – 2° elevated. Heat Stroke: May include Altered Mental Status, Seizure or other neurological dysfunction, may be without sweating. Temperature ≥ 104℉. ‌Treatment EMT AEMT Manage CABCs Remove patient from hot environment Remove clothing as needed Active cooling with continuous temperature monitoring: Move to air conditioned room Cool body and head with water or saline Fan to promote evaporative cooling Apply ice packs to groin, neck, and axilla Use ice bath if available Obtain vital signs (apply cardiac monitor) Oxygen Administration as appropriate Monitor EtCO2 and Waveform Capnography Consider Supraglottic Airway if indicated and only if BVM ventilations are ineffective Obtain IV access and consider NS administration (use chilled NS if heat stroke suspected) ADULT: IV NS 500 mL bolus, if no signs of pulmonary edema Repeat up to 2 L NS if: Fatigue remains and/or Altered Mental Status remains and/or SBP < 100 mmHg, if no signs of pulmonary edema Paramedic PEDIATRIC: IV NS 20 mL/kg bolus, if no signs of pulmonary edema Repeat up to 60 mL/kg if: Fatigue remains and/or Altered Mental Status remains and/or SBP < (70 + 2x age in years) mmHg, if no signs of pulmonary edema ECG monitoring (see Cardiac Monitor Operation) Fever Rice University Emergency Medical Services Clinical Guidelines Criteria hypotensive symptoms and no signs of pulmonary edema PEDIATRIC: IV NS TKO if SBP ≥ (70+2x age in years) mmHg without hypotensive symptoms IV NS 20 mL/kg bolus if SBP < (70 + 2x age in years) mmHg with hypotensive symptoms and no signs of pulmonary edema Repeat up to 60 mL/kg if SBP remains < (70 + 2x age in years) mmHg with hypotensive symptoms and no signs of pulmonary edema If patient has nausea and/or vomiting, consider: ADULT: Ondansetron 4-8 mg IV If no history of prolonged QT Syndrome PEDIATRIC: Ondansetron 0.1 mg/kg IV (max 4 mg) If no history of prolonged QT syndrome General Fever with hypotension that is refractory to fluid therapy indicates severe septic shock Do not delay transport, and ensure ALS transport is enroute Hypertensive Emergency Rice University Emergency Medical Services Clinical Guidelines Criteria Symptomatic hypertension Chest pain, dyspnea, or other related symptoms of ischemia Severe headache Treatment EMT ‌AEMT Paramedic Obtain vital signs (apply cardiac monitor) including manual blood pressure Oxygen Administration as appropriate Los Angeles Prehospital Stroke Screen Elevate head to 15° Obtain 12-lead ECG Obtain IV Access If SBP > 180 mmHg and/or DBP > 120 mmHg AND chest pain or dyspnea: ADULT: Nitroglycerin 0.4 mg SL May repeat every 5 min until BP reduced 10% or symptoms resolved DO NOT reduce BP beyond 10% Medical command consult required if patient ≤ 40 years old May be administered as tablets or powders Nitroglycerine is contraindicated in patients with: History of aortic stenosis Use of Viagra (Sildenafil) or Levitra (Vardenafil) within last 24 hrs Use of Cialis (Tadalafil) within last 48 hrs Suspected right sided MI, as it may precipitate hypotension PEDIATRIC: Consult medical command General Do NOT treat asymptomatic hypertension. Do NOT reduce BP in symptomatic hypertension by more than 10%. A hypertensive emergency means end-organ damage and therefore assessment should include ACS, stroke, and renal failure. Neonatal Resuscitation Rice University Emergency Medical Services Clinical Guidelines Criteria Newborn patients who do not respond to initial stimulation and resuscitation Example: weak cry, signs of respiratory distress, poor tone Prompt initial resuscitation steps are critical to the successful outcome of a neonatal resuscitation. Treatment EMT Advanced EMT Position the newborn on their back, with the airway in sniﬃng position. Suction the mouth and then nose using bulb suction if thick meconium or secretions are present Dry the newborn, then place on a dry blanket, cover the head, and keep warm. ‌Provide tactile stimulation if the newborn is not responding to drying Record APGAR score at 1 min. and at 5 min. If the HR < 100 bpm, gasping, or apnea: Positive pressure ventilations with room air at 40 to 60 breaths/min. The primary indicator of eﬀective ventilation is heart rate improvement. Use minimum necessary volume to achieve chest rise and heart rate change. If there is no improvement after 90 seconds, ventilate with oxygen until heart rate normalizes, then reassess. If HR < 60 bpm: Positive pressure ventilations with oxygen at 40 to 60 breaths/min. If no improvements after 30 seconds, begin chest compressions at 3:1 ratio 90 compressions and 30 breaths/min Blood glucose analysis using a heal prick. Hypoglycemia in a newborn is defined as: BGL ≤ 30mg/dL in the first 24 hours of life BGL ≤ 45mg/dL thereafter Treat using the hypoglycemia protocol. If ventilation and heart rate are not improved after 3 minutes of adequate resuscitation: IV Normal Saline 10 mL/kg IV over 5 to 10 minutes If persistent obtundation AND suspicion or evidence of maternal narcotic use: Naloxone 0.1mg/kg IV/IO/IN (Max Dose 0.4 mg) every 5 minutes up to a total of 4 mg Paramedic Continuous ECG monitoring and treat life threatening dysrhythmias as indicated If heart rate < 60 and no chest rise during ventilation, intubate. If the heart rate remains < 60 despite adequate ventilation and chest compressions, consider: Epinephrine [1:10,000] 0.01 mg/kg IV, may be repeated every 3 to 5 minutes if heart rate remains < 60 bpm. Obtain APGAR scores at 1 and 5 minutes of life Obstetric Emergencies Rice University Emergency Medical Services Clinical Guidelines Criteria Obstetric emergencies can include a broad array of conditions found in women of childbearing age. For any female patient with a specific complaint of abdominal pain, vaginal bleeding or discharge, and/or nonspeciﬁc shock/hypotension, an obstetric emergency should be considered. Obtaining pertinent information during a patient interview will help to identify conditions/complaints that should be seen without delay in the emergency room, and conditions/complaints that would be more appropriately seen by the patient’s physician. Maternal changes over the pregnancy can aﬀect a woman’s body: A growing abdomen becomes more prone to injury. Balance and gait may be aﬀected. ‌A pregnant woman’s blood volume increases by almost 50% by the time she reaches term. During pregnancy, the heart rate increases by 10 – 15 bpm. Blood pressure may be lower than normal in the first two trimesters but returns to normal in the third trimester. Hypertension in a pregnant woman should raise suspicion for pre-eclampsia. Increased maternal blood volume delays ﬁndings associated with shock. Slight shortness of breath is a common complaint in late pregnancy. Severe nausea and vomiting (hyperemesis gravidarum) may occur in early pregnancy. Pregnancy causes musculoskeletal joints to loosen – sprains and strains may occur more readily. Concerning ﬁndings that should increase the suspicion of an emergent condition include: Unusually heavy vaginal bleeding (menorrhagia): Saturating a tampon or sanitary napkin as frequently as every hour for more than four hours is signiﬁcant and the patient should be evaluated for hypovolemia/ hemorrhaging shock. Unusual abdominal pain: Severe or unusual abdominal pain may be caused by premature labor, ectopic pregnancy, spontaneous abortion, placenta previa or placental abruption, as well as other abdominal complaints such as appendicitis, kidney stones, etc. Trauma in pregnancy: The increased vascularity of the uterus, as well as other physiologic changes in the pregnant patient, increases the risk of serious maternal injury, and/or fetal distress. Medical command should be consulted as needed for assistance with appropriate destination for patients with obstetric complaints. Note: Remember, two patients = two charts. General Treatment Priorities EMT Supportive care Obtain vital signs (apply cardiac monitor) Rapid transport if needed, position the patient carefully: To prevent supine hypotensive syndrome and further impairment in maternal and fetal perfusion, never position a patient in the third trimester of pregnancy in a supine position for transport. Consider laying the patient on their left side to avoid pressure on the vena cava. Pre-eclampsia/Eclampsia Criteria Pre-eclampsia is the new onset of hypertension and either protein in the urine or end-organ dysfunction after 20 weeks of gestation in a previously normotensive woman. Eclampsia is the development of grand mal seizures in a woman with preeclampsia, in the absence of other neurological conditions that could account for the seizure. Note that eclampsia may occur up to 30 days post-delivery. Indications for preeclampsia/eclampsia: Severe hypertension (SBP ≥ 160 mmHg or DBP ≥ 110 mmHg) Peripheral edema Persistent and/or severe headache Visual abnormalities ‌Upper abdominal pain or epigastric pain Nausea and/or vomiting Dyspnea and/or retrosternal chest pain Altered mental status Treatment EMT AEMT Manage CABCs Obtain vital signs (apply cardiac monitor) Oxygen Administration as appropriate Place patient in left lateral recumbent position if possible If seizing or postictal, treat per Seizures guideline Consider IV access and NS administration ADULT: IV NS TKO if SBP ≥ 100 mmHg without hypotensive symptoms IV NS 250 mL bolus if SBP < 100 mmHg with hypotensive symptoms and no signs of pulmonary edema Repeat up to 1 L NS if SBP remains < 100 mmHg with hypotensive symptoms and no signs of pulmonary edema Vaginal Bleeding Criteria Vaginal bleeding can be caused by: abruptio placenta placenta previa uterine rupture miscarriage postpartum hemorrhage Treatment EMT and transport to the closest appropriate facility. AEMT Manage CABCs Obtain vital signs (apply cardiac monitor) ‌Oxygen Administration as appropriate Positioning: If in the third trimester of pregnancy, place the patient in the left lateral recumbent position. If not in the third trimester and is exhibiting signs/symptoms of hypoperfusion, place the patient in Trendelenburg position. If active postpartum hemorrhage from the vagina, apply a ﬁrm uterine massage starting from the pubis toward the umbilicus clockwise. If miscarriage and the fetus is < 20 weeks in gestation: If pulseless and apneic, do not attempt resuscitation measures for the fetus. If there is any question as to the approximate gestation of the fetus, provide neonatal resuscitative measures. If spontaneous respirations and/or pulses, provide immediate Neonatal Resuscitation If miscarriage and the fetus is ≥ 20 weeks in gestation: Immediate Neonatal Resuscitation Consider IV access and NS administration ADULT: IV NS TKO if SBP ≥ 100 mmHg without hypotensive symptoms IV NS 250 mL bolus if SBP < 100 mmHg with hypotensive symptoms and no signs of pulmonary edema Repeat up to 1 L NS if SBP remains < 100 mmHg with hypotensive symptoms and no signs of pulmonary edema Labor and Delivery Uncomplicated Delivery An important decision to make with patients in labor is whether to attempt delivery in the ﬁeld or transport the patient to the hospital. Factors that affect that decision include: Frequent contractions that are less than 2 minutes apart and lasting 30 – 45 seconds. Crowning or bulging Mother has the urge to push or move her bowels. Do not allow the patient to utilize the toilet. Number of previous deliveries.
If determined that delivery in the field is best for the patient:
‌Treatment

EMT Manage CABCs Obtain vital signs (apply cardiac monitor) Oxygen Administration as appropriate Place patient supine with knees bent and widely separated. Elevate buttocks if needed. Carefully assist expulsion of the newborn from the birth canal in its natural progression. Provide gentle pressure with palm to control delivery of the head. Do not pull the newborn. As the head emerges, encourage the mother not to push so that the delivery process can continue slowly and with minimal trauma to the perineal area. Gently guide the head downward (posterior) until the upper (anterior) shoulder delivers. If the cord is wrapped around the newborn’s neck, attempt to unwrap it from the neck. If unable, attach 2 umbilical clamps and cut the cord between the clamps. Gently lift the head upwards (anterior) until the lower (posterior) shoulder delivers. Do not routinely suction the newborn’s mouth and nose to clear secretions, unless there is an obvious airway obstruction or requires positive pressure ventilations. Once delivery is accomplished, position the infant at or slightly below the level of the vagina, clamp the cord at 6” and 8” from the navel, and cut between the clamps. Dry and wrap the newborn in a blanket to preserve body temperature. Note the delivery time and the sex of newborn. Record APGAR score at 1 min and at 5 min post-delivery. Provide immediate Neonatal Resuscitation if necessary. If the placenta is delivered (separation usually occurs within 5 min after delivery), ensure it is transported to the hospital. After delivery, massaging the uterus and allowing the infant to nurse will promote uterine contraction and help control bleeding.

AEMT Consider IV access and NS administration ADULT: IV NS TKO if SBP ≥ 100 mmHg without hypotensive symptoms IV NS 250 mL bolus if SBP < 100 mmHg with hypotensive symptoms and no signs of pulmonary edema Repeat up to 1 L NS if SBP remains < 100 mmHg with hypotensive symptoms and no signs of pulmonary edema

Activity (muscle tone)
Arms and legs extended
Active movement with ﬂexed arms and legs
Pulse (heart rate)
Grimace (response to stimulation)
No response
Facial grimace
Sneeze, cough, pulls away

Blue-gray, pale
Pink body, blue extremities
