Slow, irregular
Good, crying
Consider using the APGAR Score on mdcalc.com.
Prolapsed Cord

Prolapsed cord occurs when the umbilical cord presents itself outside of the uterus while the fetus is still inside. It can occur when the water breaks: with the release of amniotic fluid, the cord can follow.
Usually, the fetus will engage and compress the cord, resulting in fetal hypoxia.

EMT Place the patient in the knee-chest position. Consider a prone knee-chest position. Palpate the cord for a pulse (excessive palpation may cause vasospasm, potentially leading to a worse outcome): If no pulse, elevate the presenting fetal part. This is generally performed by placing 2 fingers or an entire hand in the vagina to elevate the fetus off the cord. Wrap the cord in saline soaked dressing. Do not attempt to push the cord back into the vagina. ‌Provide immediate transport to the closest appropriate facility while maintaining elevation of the presenting fetal part.

AEMT Consider IV access and NS administration ADULT: IV NS TKO if SBP ≥ 100 mmHg without hypotensive symptoms IV NS 250 mL bolus if SBP < 100 mmHg with hypotensive symptoms and no signs of pulmonary edema Repeat up to 1 L NS if SBP remains < 100 mmHg with hypotensive symptoms and no signs of pulmonary edema
Presenting Limb
When faced with a newborn’s limb as the presenting part do not attempt delivery in the prehospital setting.
Breech Presentation
Breech presentation occurs when a newborn’s buttocks is the presenting part. Let the delivery occur naturally and ensure that an open airway is provided until delivery is completed.

EMT Place the patient supine with knees widely separated. Elevate the patient’s buttocks, if needed. Allow the delivery to proceed normally while supporting the newborn with the palm of your hand and arm to prevent explosive delivery. If the head delivers slowly or becomes trapped in the birth canal: place a gloved hand in the vagina, with the palm towards the newborn’s face utilizing a “V” technique with your fingers ‌push the vaginal wall away from the newborn’s face to create a space until delivery of the head. Check the cord to ensure that it is not wrapped around the newborn’s neck.

AEMT Consider IV access and NS administration ADULT: IV NS TKO if SBP ≥ 100 mmHg without hypotensive symptoms IV NS 250 mL bolus if SBP < 100 mmHg with hypotensive symptoms and no signs of pulmonary edema Repeat up to 1 L NS if SBP remains < 100 mmHg with hypotensive symptoms and no signs of pulmonary edema
Shoulder Dystocia

Shoulder dystocia occurs when, after normal delivery of the head, the newborn’s shoulders cannot pass through the pelvic outlet, interrupting delivery. Typically, after the head is delivered it will retract tightly against the perineum.

EMT Place the patient supine with knees widely separated. Elevate the patient’s buttocks. Hyperflex mother’s legs into a knee-chest position (McRoberts maneuver), allowing her pubic symphysis to slide over the infant’s anterior shoulder, flattering the maternal sacrum. If McRoberts maneuver fails, also apply suprapubic pressure to displace the infant posteriorly. Apply pressure just above the pubic symphysis, not the uterine fundus.

AEMT ‌Consider IV access and NS administration ADULT: IV NS TKO if SBP ≥ 100 mmHg without hypotensive symptoms IV NS 250 mL bolus if SBP < 100 mmHg with hypotensive symptoms and no signs of pulmonary edema Repeat up to 1 L NS if SBP remains < 100 mmHg with hypotensive symptoms and no signs of pulmonary edema
‌Uterine Inversion

Uterine inversion occurs when the uterine fundus collapses into the endometrial cavity, turning the uterus partially or completely inside out. It is a rare complication of vaginal delivery, but when it occurs it is life-threatening.

EMT Place the patient supine. If the placenta is still attached, do not remove it. Make one attempt to manually replace the inverted uterus by placing a hand inside the vagina and pushing the fundus along the long axis of the vagina toward the umbilicus. If a constriction ring is palpable, pressure should be applied to the part of the fundus nearest the ring to ease it through from bottom to top. If unsuccessful, cover any protruding tissue lightly with moist sterile dressings.

AEMT Consider IV access and NS administration ADULT: IV NS TKO if SBP ≥ 100 mmHg without hypotensive symptoms IV NS 250 mL bolus if SBP < 100 mmHg with hypotensive symptoms and no signs of pulmonary edema Repeat up to 1 L NS if SBP remains < 100 mmHg with hypotensive symptoms and no signs of pulmonary edema
‌Oleoresin Capsicum (OC) Spray Exposure
Rice University Emergency Medical Services Clinical Guidelines
Exposure to Oleoresin Capsicum (OC, pepper) spray
Services requested by RUPD Prior to scene entry, all providers must:
Use a face shield and eye protection
N95 mask should be worn
Gloves should also be worn

Minimize exposure to equipment and clothing Treatment EMT Manage CABCs Obtain vital signs (apply cardiac monitor) Oxygen Administration as appropriate Remove contaminated clothing if possible and practical. Remove contact lenses if present. Place patient in a position of comfort as allowed by law enforcement. Irrigate face and eyes: Copious irrigation and time will relieve symptoms Use of running water, such as showers or hoses, is preferable to saline Irrigate for at least 10 minutes or until symptoms reside If any open wounds have been contaminated, irrigate as described above Assess breath sounds If patient complains of respiratory distress, treat per Dyspnea Guidelines. Proceed with extreme caution if patient has a history of asthma or respiratory disease. General

Individuals exposed to pepper spray may experience increased difficulty with respirations and are at risk for positional asphyxiation. Ensure that any patient with shortness of breath or other respiratory difficulty is placed in a position that allows minimal respiration effort.

Individuals exposed to pepper spray may concurrently exhibit signs of excited delirium, including but not limited to combativeness, hyperthermia, and restlessness. These individuals require immediate transport and ALS intervention. Treat these patients with symptomatic care and reference the appropriate protocols as necessary.
Additional attention is necessary to prevent the unnecessary exposure of personnel and equipment. ‌Respiratory Arrest Rice University Emergency Medical Services Clinical Guidelines Criteria

Not breathing but has a pulse. Treatment EMT AEMT Paramedic Establish airway patency with positioning Oxygen Administration and BVM ventilations as appropriate Obtain vital signs (apply cardiac monitor) Determine a Blood Glucose Level Obtain 12-lead ECG Monitor EtCO2 and Waveform Capnography Consider Supraglottic Airway if indicated and only if BVM ventilations are ineffective Obtain IV access Toxins/drug/narcotic/opiate overdose suspected with apnea or ineffective/agonal breathing: ADULT or PEDIATRIC ≥ 25 kg: Naloxone 0.4 mg IVP/IOP/IM/IN, may repeat every 2 to 5 minutes to a maximum of 4 mg Use Naloxone to restore effective breathing Avoid excessive dosing to prevent withdrawal If available, Consider Single-Use 4 mg Nasal Narcan Spray PEDIATRIC < 25: Naloxone 0.1 mg/kg (Max Dose 0.4 mg) IVP/IOP/IM/IN, may repeat every 5 minutes to a maximum of 4 mg ECG monitoring (see Cardiac Monitor Operation) Consider advanced airway management if indicated and only if individually credentialed General
As with any airway management scenario, the least invasive method is usually preferred. ‌Seizures Rice University Emergency Medical Services Clinical Guidelines Criteria

Suspected seizures Treatment EMT AEMT Obtain vital signs (apply cardiac monitor) Determine a Blood Glucose Level Oxygen Administration as appropriate and consider BVM ventilations Assess patient for possible trauma and treat as appropriate Place patient in recovery position post-seizure Monitor EtCO2 and Waveform Capnography Obtain IV access and consider NS administration ADULT: IV NS TKO if SBP ≥ 100 mmHg without hypotensive symptoms IV NS 250 mL bolus if SBP < 100 mmHg with hypotensive symptoms and no signs of pulmonary edema Repeat up to 2 L NS if SBP remains < 100 mmHg with hypotensive symptoms and no signs of pulmonary edema PEDIATRIC: IV NS TKO if SBP ≥ (70+2x age in years) mmHg without hypotensive symptoms IV NS 20 mL/kg bolus if SBP < (70 + 2x age in years) mmHg with hypotensive symptoms and no signs of pulmonary edema Repeat up to 60 mL/kg if SBP remains < (70 + 2x age in years) mmHg with hypotensive symptoms and no signs of pulmonary edema Hypoglycemia suspected (BGL < 60 mg/dL): ADULT or PEDIATRIC ≥ 25 kg: D10 5 mL/kg IV/IO (up to 250 mL) OR D25 2 mL/kg IVP/IOP (up to 100 mL) OR D50 1 mL/kg IVP/IOP (up to 50 mL) OR Glucagon 1 mg IM if no vascular access obtained PEDIATRIC < 25 kg: D10 5 mL/kg IV/IO (up to 250 mL) OR D25 2 mL/kg IVP/IOP (up to 100 mL) OR D50 1 mL/kg IVP/IOP (up to 50 mL) OR Glucagon 0.03 mg/kg IM (maximum 1 mg) if no vascular access obtained General

D10 should be administered as a piggyback drip, or into an extension set, using a macro drip set with a dose of 5 mL/kg IV/IO up to 250 mL. D10 may be given with the drip wide open. Once the patient regains consciousness, the drip should be shut down, and the BGL reassessed. No further Dextrose should be administered if the BGL is > 60 mg/dL. ‌Stroke/CVA Rice University Emergency Medical Services Clinical Guidelines Criteria

Suspected stroke Treatment EMT AEMT Rapid assessment: To identify stroke: Los Angeles Prehospital Stroke Screen If positive, to identify likely LVO: Rapid Arterial oCclusion Evaluation Identify time last known well Obtain vital signs (apply cardiac monitor) Determine a Blood Glucose Level Oxygen Administration and BVM ventilations as appropriate Rapid transport to stroke center (see Destination Determination) Rapid assessment and transport Monitor EtCO2 and Waveform Capnography Consider Supraglottic Airway if indicated and only if BVM ventilations are ineffective Obtain IV access and consider NS administration ADULT: IV NS TKO if SBP ≥ 100 mmHg without hypotensive symptoms IV NS 250 mL bolus if SBP < 100 mmHg with hypotensive symptoms and no signs of pulmonary edema Repeat up to 2 L NS if SBP remains < 100 mmHg with hypotensive symptoms and no signs of pulmonary edema Consider 12-lead ECG General

The patient may still be experiencing a stroke even if the screening criteria are not met. ‌Rice University Emergency Medical Services Clinical Guidelines Trauma Assessment & Treatment ‌Trauma General Assessment: Adult and Pediatric Rice University Emergency Medical Services Clinical Guidelines Treatment Priorities
Assessment SCENE SAFETY PROTECTIVE EQUIPMENT Primary Survey Secondary Survey (when appropriate)
Primary Survey Care Control arterial bleeding Open airway Seal any penetrating wounds from neck to navel
Ongoing Care Reassess all primary care Support oxygenation/ventilation Vascular access Secondary Survey (if able) Keep patient warm/avoid hypothermia

Appropriate Destination General Before entering any trauma scene, ensure your personal safety. Do not attempt patient contact until hazards can be appropriately mitigated. In addition to scene safety, consider mechanisms of injury, number of patients, and special equipment or extrication needs. All trauma patients should be assessed utilizing primary, secondary and reassessment surveys. Primary Survey

The primary survey is to be conducted on all trauma patients. It is designed to rapidly identify life-threatening or potentially life-threatening injuries. The primary survey should be completed within 2 minutes of patient contact. The primary survey is only interrupted for life-threatening arterial bleeding, airway obstruction, or respiratory/cardiac arrest.

Primary survey interventions include airway management, sealing open chest wounds, identifying suspected tension pneumothorax, oxygen administration, and controlling any obvious external hemorrhage. Remember to expose the patient as needed to conduct an appropriate exam.

The following are steps of the primary survey: Manually stabilize the cervical spine while assessing the airway and level of consciousness. Evaluate breathing – present? rapid? normal? slow? shallow? Evaluate circulation – carotid and radial pulses present? Control external hemorrhage. Examine for deformity, contusions, abrasions, penetrations, burns, lacerations, tenderness, or swelling (“DCAP-BTLS”): Head Neck – subcutaneous emphysema? Chest – paradoxical movement? Auscultate the chest for breath sounds in the mid-axilla bilaterally – present? equal? Examine the abdomen and pelvis for deformity, contusions, abrasions, penetrations, burns, lacerations, tenderness, or swelling (“DCAP-BTLS”). Examine the extremities for deformity, contusions, abrasions, penetrations, burns, lacerations, tenderness, or swelling (“DCAP-BTLS”), and pulse, movement, sensation. Any trauma patient with altered level of consciousness, abnormal respiration, abnormal circulation, or signs/conditions likely to lead to shock (distended abdomen, pelvic instability, bilateral femur fractures) should be rapidly immobilized and ambulance transport should be contacted after completing the primary survey. These are “LOAD & GO” patients. Secondary Survey
The secondary survey is always done enroute on critical patients.
If no critical conditions are found in the primary survey, the secondary survey may be conducted on the scene and should be completed within 5 minutes after the primary survey is completed.

The following are steps of the secondary survey: Obtain vital signs (pulse, respiratory rate, blood pressure, pulse oximetry) Obtain history of traumatic event and pertinent patient medical history (allergies, medications, past illness/injury, last oral intake) Head to toe exam – look for “DCAP-BLS” in every body area. Calculate GCS score Perform indicated bandaging and splinting Reassessment Survey
The reassessment survey is an abbreviated exam after interventions and done at least every 5 minutes for critical patients.

The following are steps of the reassessment survey: Repeat the primary survey Repeat vital signs Repeat GCS score calculation Check every intervention – proper placement of advanced airway? Proper placement of IV/IO? Check results of every intervention – improved oxygenation/ventilation? Improved vitals? Note: Patients who appear to have traumatic injuries may also have a medical complaint. Focused assessment, and reassessment, of every patient, medical or traumatic, should be conducted to identify all life-threatening conditions and treat as appropriate. ‌Animal Bites and Stings Rice University Emergency Medical Services Clinical Guidelines Treatment Priorities
If an allergic reaction occurs, treat per Allergic Reaction and Anaphylaxis.
Make sure the scene is safe before beginning treatment.
Request assistance from RUPD and animal control if needed.
If safe, take a photo of the animal for the hospital.
If the bite/sting is on an extremity, remove any jewelry or constricting clothing.
Mark the edge of any swelling/irritation every 20 minutes.
Keep the patient calm. Animal bites carry a risk for infection and may require evaluation in the ER.
Dog and cat bites may require prophylactic treatment, especially bites to the hands, puncture wounds, and crush injuries. Cat bites are at a particularly high risk for infection.

Rabies should be suspected in animals who display symptoms such as inappetence, dysphagia, abnormal behavior, ataxia, paralysis, altered vocalization, or seizures: Skunks, racoons, and bats are commonly infected, and injuries from these animals should be seen in the ER. Small rodents such as squirrels, chipmunks, rats, and mice are rarely infected with rabies and have not been known to transmit rabies to humans. Treatment EMT For snake bites: For dog/cat bites: For ant bites: Elevate the injury above the level of the heart, if possible. Loosely bandage and transport to a hospital-based ER. Consider trauma center. Do not apply cold packs or tourniquets. Manage major bleeding and any immediate life threats. Thoroughly clean wounds. Warm water and soap are preferred if available. Consider transport to ER for possible disease transmission, especially if the animal was not domesticated or is showing signs of rabies. ER treatment should also be considered to assess for possible fractures, retained foreign bodies (like teeth), and ligament/tendon injury. Move the patient to a safe area and brush oﬀ any remaining ants. Wash aﬀected area with soap and water. Apply hydrocortisone cream to the aﬀected area for itching/burning. Assess for allergic reaction. Refer to Allergic Reaction and Anaphylaxis guidelines. For asp caterpillar stings: For squirrel and other rodent bites: AEMT Use tape to carefully remove any remaining hairs embedded in the skin. Wash aﬀected area with soap and water. Assess for allergic reaction. Refer to Allergic Reaction and Anaphylaxis guidelines. Thoroughly clean wounds. Warm water and soap are preferred if available. Use pressure to stop bleeding and bandage appropriately. Obtain IV access and consider NS administration ADULT: IV NS TKO if SBP ≥ 100 mmHg without hypotensive symptoms IV NS 250 mL bolus if SBP < 100 mmHg with hypotensive symptoms and no signs of pulmonary edema Repeat up to 2 L NS if SBP remains < 100 mmHg with hypotensive symptoms and no signs of pulmonary edema PEDIATRIC: IV NS TKO if SBP ≥ (70+2x age in years) mmHg without hypotensive symptoms IV NS 20 mL/kg bolus if SBP < (70 + 2x age in years) mmHg with hypotensive symptoms and no signs of pulmonary edema Repeat up to 60 mL/kg if SBP remains < (70 + 2x age in years) mmHg with hypotensive symptoms and no signs of pulmonary edema ‌Amputation Rice University Emergency Medical Services Clinical Guidelines Criteria: A traumatic amputation is the loss of a body part, such as a finger, toe, arm, or leg, that occurs suddenly due to an accident or injury. Amputations can either be partial, in which some soft tissue is still connected, or complete, in which the body part is completely separated from the body. Treatment EMT Advanced EMT Pediatric CABCs Oxygen via NC or NRB as appropriate Apply tourniquet if bleeding continues despite direct pressure per “Life Threatening Hemorrhaging” protocol Obtain Vital signs Splint suspected fractures including joint above and below area of injury Cover amputated anatomy with saline-moistened gauze and place in a clean plastic bag. Then, place the bag containing the wrapped amputated anatomy over ice, avoiding direct contact of amputated anatomy with ice Stabilize impaled objects IV Normal Saline TKO if systolic BP ≥100 mmHg without symptoms of hypotension IV Normal Saline 250 mL bolus if systolic BP < 100 mmHg with symptoms of hypotension and no signs of pulmonary edema May repeat up to a total of 2 Liters Normal Saline if systolic BP remains < 100 mmHg with symptoms of hypotension and no signs of pulmonary edema Consider assisting with ventilation as needed. BLS airway or advanced airway such as the Air-Q or endotracheal intubation, if credentialed to do so and procedure is indicated IV Normal Saline 20 mL/kg bolus if systolic BP < (70 ÷ 2x age in years) mmHg and no signs of pulmonary edema May repeat up to a total of 60 mL/kg if systolic BP < (70 ÷ 2x age in years) mmHg and no signs of pulmonary edema General: Amputations have the potential for massive hemorrhage, but most often, the bleeding will control itself with pressure applied to the stump. If bleeding cannot be controlled with pressure, a tourniquet may be used. ‌Burns Rice University Emergency Medical Services Clinical Guidelines General
Thermal burn Irrigate with water only if ﬂames not extinguished, smoldering present, or signiﬁcant heat is still being dissipated Determine possibility of smoke/toxic inhalation
Chemical burn Consult Safety Data Sheet (SDS) Consult Environmental Health Safety and Lab Operations Brush oﬀ dry chemicals Irrigate with water for at least 15 min

Electrical burn Evaluate airway and cardiac status Treatment EMT AEMT Paramedic Scene safety Stop burning process. Remove all burned/burning clothing and any jewelry Trauma and Hypovolemic Shock supportive care Assess for respiratory symptoms and examine face/neck/airway for burns Oxygen Administration and BVM ventilations as appropriate Stabilize impaled objects if explosive mechanism of injury If burn is < 10% BSA: cool with water (preferred) or sterile saline If burn is ≥ 10% BSA: cover with sterile dry dressing (consider non-adhesive dressing) Monitor EtCO2 and Waveform Capnography if respiratory symptoms Consider Supraglottic Airway if indicated and only if BVM ventilations are ineffective Obtain 12-lead ECG if electrical burn If major thermal burn, administer IV NS: ADULT: NS 500 mL/hr IV/IO, monitor for signs of pulmonary edema PEDIATRIC: If age < 5 years: NS 125 mL/hr IV/IO If age 6 – 13 years: NS 250 mL/hr IV/IO ECG monitoring if electrical burn, treat per Cardiac Rhythm Abnormalities guideline ‌General
If patient’s clothes are burning or smoldering, douse them with water immediately. If water is not available, roll the patient on the ground or smother the fire. Do not touch or pick up debris.

Consider advanced airway management for patients with: Full thickness burns of face or perioral region Circumferential neck burns Acute respiratory distress Progressive hoarseness or air hunger Respiratory depression Altered mental status Airway edema Percent Body Surface Area (BSA) Estimation Chart Note: count only partial-thickness and full-thickness burns when calculating estimated % BSA. An alternate method of calculating %BSA involvement is to use the size of the patient’s entire hand as equal to 1% of their BSA. This is a useful method when calculating smaller burn areas. ‌Chest, Abdomen, and Pelvis Trauma Rice University Emergency Medical Services Clinical Guidelines Criteria

Blunt or penetrating injury to the chest, abdomen, or pelvis Treatment EMT AEMT Paramedic Consider Spinal Motion Restriction as indicated by mechanism and exam Seal open wounds from neck to navel Stabilize impaled objects Apply pelvic binder for suspected pelvic fractures Cover eviscerated organs with sterile, saline-dampened dressing layered with dry dressings Obtain vital signs (apply cardiac monitor) Oxygen Administration and BVM ventilations as appropriate Monitor EtCO2 and Waveform Capnography Consider Supraglottic Airway if indicated and only if BVM ventilations are ineffective Obtain IV access and consider NS administration ADULT: IV NS bolus to maintain MAP > 65 mmHg, EXCEPT IF: Suspected head injury Female patient with suspected pregnancy Age ≥ 40 years old Known history of hypertension and/or coronary artery disease PEDIATRIC: IV NS 20 mL/kg bolus if SBP < (70 + 2x age in years) mmHg with hypotensive symptoms and no signs of pulmonary edema Repeat up to 60 mL/kg if SBP remains < (70 + 2x age in years) mmHg with hypotensive symptoms and no signs of pulmonary edema ECG monitoring (see Cardiac Monitor Operation) Consider advanced airway management if indicated and only if individually credentialled General
Prioritize calling for transport as soon as injuries are realized
Ensure correct pelvic binder usage (see diagram below)
Purpose of the pelvic binder is to secure the pelvis closer to its natural position to control bleeding ‌Pelvic Binder Application
Indications: Blunt force trauma or blast injury consistent with mechanism causing an “open-book” pelvic fracture and any of the following: Pelvic instability Hemodynamic instability/shock Pelvic pain
Contraindications: None ‌Compartment Syndrome Rice University Emergency Medical Services Clinical Guidelines Criteria
History of trauma in extremity in past days or acutely that could cause pressure to build in deep spaces of extremity, hindering perfusion of surrounding tissues. Treatment Priorities
Vital signs
5 P’s exam (see description below)

Notification of concern regarding limb circulation compromise during transfer of care Treatment EMT Trauma and Hypovolemic Shock supportive care Control bleeding with direct pressure Position extremity to promote circulation to distal extremity Oxygen Administration and BVM ventilations as appropriate Obtain vital signs (apply cardiac monitor) Evaluate extremity for 5 P’s of compartment syndrome: Pain out of proportion to assessed injury Paresthesia (numbness, tingling, or burning sensation due to nerve compression) Pressure with palpation (skin/muscle feels tense due to increasing force within compartment) Paralysis (late sign due to nerve compression) Pulselessness in distal extremity (late sign) General
Do not move entrapped patient unless in danger.
Do not attempt to splint injuries. ‌Eye Injury Rice University Emergency Medical Services Clinical Guidelines Criteria
Blunt or penetrating trauma to the eye or surrounding areas

Foreign objects in the eye or surrounding areas (i.e. chemicals, debris, etc.) Treatment EMT Manage CABCs Check visual acuity (if possible) Obtain vital signs (apply cardiac monitor) For chemical exposure: Brush off solid chemical prior to flushing Continually flush affected eye with saline or water (if available) Check any relevant SDS sheets for instructions and recommendations for appropriate eye washing time and technique Consult Environmental Health Safety and Lab Operations For open injury to globe (or any non-superficial injury to the eye): Patch both eyes Do not put pressure on or manipulate the eyes Do not administer any medication into eyes Elevate head if possible Do not allow eating or drinking ‌Head, Neck, and Spinal Trauma Rice University Emergency Medical Services Clinical Guidelines Criteria
Mechanism of injury with likely trauma to the head, neck, or spine.
Visible or palpated deformity to the head, neck, or spine. Treatment Priorities
Consider spinal motion restriction (see below).
Treat life-threatening injuries.
Do not attempt to splint individual injuries if multi-system trauma is present.
Remember, patients with neurological or focal deﬁcits can decompensate rapidly.

For suspected traumatic brain injuries, avoid hypoxia and hypotension. Treatment EMT AEMT Manage CABCs Consider spinal motion restriction (per guidelines below) Obtain vital signs (apply cardiac monitor) Oxygen Administration and BVM ventilations as appropriate Control bleeding per Life Threatening Hemorrhage Elevate patient’s head to 30° for severe head injury with mental status changes, if no contraindications Monitor EtCO2 and Waveform Capnography Consider Supraglottic Airway if indicated and only if BVM ventilations are ineffective Obtain IV access and consider NS administration ADULT: IV NS TKO if SBP ≥ 100 mmHg without hypotensive symptoms IV NS 250 mL bolus if SBP < 100 mmHg with hypotensive symptoms and no signs of pulmonary edema Repeat up to 2 L NS if SBP remains < 100 mmHg with hypotensive symptoms and no signs of pulmonary edema PEDIATRIC: IV NS TKO if SBP ≥ (70+2x age in years) mmHg without hypotensive symptoms IV NS 20 mL/kg bolus if SBP < (70 + 2x age in years) mmHg with hypotensive symptoms and no signs of pulmonary edema Repeat up to 60 mL/kg if SBP remains < (70 + 2x age in years) and no signs of pulmonary edema ‌Spinal Motion Restriction (SMR) Apply SMR if any of the following are present:
Altered mental status
Evidence of drug or alcohol intoxication
Midline neck and/or back pain and/or tenderness
Focal neurological deﬁcits or symptoms
Anatomic deformity to the spine
Distracting injury or circumstance, including extreme agitation or emotional distress
Torticollis in children (may require immobilization in position found)
A communication barrier which prevents accurate assessment

Increased suspicion of spinal injury (major MVC, axial loading injuries to the spine, substantial torso injuries, falls > 10 feet, signiﬁcant facial trauma, hanging) If SMR is indicated and patient agrees to transport:

For patients who are ambulatory on scene or can safely self-extricate: Place cervical collar on patient. Direct patient to limit spine movement. Keep the patient in the position found (have the patient sit if found standing). When a transport service arrives, allow the patient to carefully move themselves to the unloaded stretcher. Secure the patient to the stretcher in a supine position or position of comfort.

For patients who are NOT ambulatory, require extrication, display altered mental status, and/or are unable to communicate reliably: Place cervical collar on patient. Direct patient to limit spine movement. Load patient onto a scoop or backboard. When a transport service arrives, use the scoop or backboard to move the patient to the stretcher. Remove the backboard or scoop once the patient is on the stretcher, maintaining in-line spinal alignment. Secure the patient to the stretcher. Transport in supine position. The patient may remain on the backboard or scoop if removing the device would otherwise delay critical interventions/rapid transport. Special considerations:
Extremes of age and the cognitive ability of the patient to understand assessment questions.
Patients ≥ 65 years old are more prone to skeletal injury with even minimal traumatic insult.
Patients must clearly understand the language spoken AND must have the cognitive ability to comprehend the answers asked in the SMR assessment.

Immobilized patients are at high risk for aspiration secondary to nausea/vomiting or blood in the mouth. Assess adequacy of respirations in all immobilized patients. Avoid placing securing devices over the abdomen of pediatric patients.
Ensure proper padding under the shoulders to maintain neutral alignment in pediatric patients.
All patient movements should be done to limit motion of the spine.
If in doubt, apply SMR and contact a Medical Director. ‌Life Threatening Hemorrhage Rice University Emergency Medical Services Clinical Guidelines Criteria

Life threatening hemorrhaging that cannot be controlled by direct pressure should be treated with a tourniquet (extremity injuries) and/or a hemostatic agent (trunk injuries). Treatment EMT AEMT General supportive care Trauma and Hypovolemic Shock supportive care Obtain vital signs (apply cardiac monitor) Oxygen Administration and BVM ventilations as appropriate Determine if patient is taking antiplatelet agent (e.g. Aspirin) or anticoagulant (e.g. Warfarin) Apply direct pressure as indicated using manual and/or via pressure dressing If direct pressure is insufficient and bleeding is arterial and/or brisk: Apply topical hemostatic agent as indicated Maintain direct pressure while using topical hemostatic agent Notify receiving EMS personnel if hemostatic agent was used and type Apply tourniquet as indicated Multiple tourniquets may be used if bleeding continues Tourniquet should be placed as high as possible on extremity in a multi-trauma patient Monitor EtCO2 and Waveform Capnography Consider Supraglottic Airway if indicated and only if BVM ventilations are ineffective Obtain large-bore IV access and consider NS administration ADULT: IV NS bolus to maintain MAP > 65 mmHg, EXCEPT IF: Suspected head injury Female patient with suspected pregnancy Age ≥ 40 years old Known history of hypertension and/or coronary artery disease PEDIATRIC: IV NS 20 mL/kg bolus if SBP < (70 + 2x age in years) mmHg and no signs of pulmonary edema Repeat up to 60 mL/kg if SBP remains < (70 + 2x age in years) mmHg and no signs of pulmonary edema ‌Tourniquet Application
Indications: Life-threatening extremity hemorrhage

Contraindications: None Technique for the application of a Combat Application Tourniquet (CAT): (Note: this protocol uses the CAT to illustrate achieving extremity bleeding control using a tourniquet. Commercial tourniquets are proven more effective than ‘homemade’ devices. In the absence of a commercial tourniquet, ‘homemade’ devices may also help control bleeding.)

The CAT windlass uses a free-moving internal band to provide circumferential pressure to an injured and uncontrollably bleeding extremity. Once placed, keep the tourniquet secure but uncovered so that the bleeding site can be clearly monitored as well as the tourniquet itself. The time of tourniquet application should be written and secured to the patient on a piece of tape. Conscious patients may experience pain related to tourniquet use.

The CAT is applied over the extremity proximal to the bleeding site routing the self-adhering band around the extremity. Lower extremity wounds require feeding the strap through both sections of the buckle. Upper extremity wounds typically require less pressure to control and do not require feeding the strap through both sections of the buckle, though doing so is usually the optimal strategy. If a single slit of the buckle is used for arm wounds, the inner slit (closest to the windlass) is to be used.
In a multi-trauma patient, the tourniquet should be placed as high as possible on the extremity.
For all lower extremity wounds, pass the band through the outside slit of the buckle, utilizing the friction adaptor buckle which will lock the band in place.
Pull the self-adhering band tight and secure the band back on itself with the Velcro-adhesive strap.

Twist the windlass until the bleeding stops. This will typically be at or less than three complete rotations of the windlass. More could be required, but be careful not to exert too much torque on the windlass to avoid breakage.
Lock the rod in place with the windlass clip.
Secure the rod with the strap by pulling it tight and adhering it to the opposite hook on the windlass hook. Indicate the time of tourniquet application on tape.

If one tourniquet correctly applied does not completely control hemorrhaging, in addition to direct pressure, an additional tourniquet may be applied just proximal to the first tourniquet. For lower extremity bleeding, two tourniquets are typically required.

Once bleeding has been controlled by a tourniquet, the usual and customary practice is to leave the tourniquet in place throughout the remainder of scene care and transport to an emergency department. ‌Hemostatic Agent Application
Indications: Life-threatening hemorrhage unable to be controlled by direct pressure If extremity wound, consider tourniquet use (see above)
Contraindications: None Technique for the application of a hemostatic agent (QuikClot):
Open clothing around wound. Remove any excess pooled blood, while preserving any clots already in the wound if possible.
Locate source of bleeding and pack gauze into wound directly onto bleeding source. More than one may be required.
Apply direct pressure until bleeding stops (typically within 3 – 5 minutes).
Leave QuikClot in place. Wrap to secure the product in the wound.
Notify receiving EMS/hospital personnel if hemostatic agent was used and what time it was packed in wound. ‌Extremity Injury Rice University Emergency Medical Services Clinical Guidelines Criteria

Significant trauma to an extremity Treatment EMT Manage CABCs Trauma and Hypovolemic Shock supportive care Obtain vital signs (apply cardiac monitor) Oxygen Administration and BVM ventilations as appropriate Splint suspected fractures including joint above and below area of injury Apply cold pack to the injury site, avoid direct contact with skin Control bleeding per Life Threatening Hemorrhage: Apply topical hemostatic agent as indicated Apply tourniquet as indicated Sexual Assault: Adult and Pediatric Rice University Emergency Medical Services Clinical Guidelines Treatment Priorities
Physical and emotional supportive care

Transport to sexual assault exam capable destination Treatment EMT AEMT General supportive care. Refrain from touching the patient without permission. Clear communication is essential. Obtain vital signs (apply cardiac monitor if given permission). Check for secondary wounds and consider treating as appropriate. Allow the patient to change clothes. Keep clothing in a bag and transfer it to the hospital or forensic nurse examiner. Discourage the patient from showering, but weigh the risks/beneﬁts with the patient if they desire to shower for comfort. Try to have a provider of the same gender on scene ‌Consider IV access and NS administration ADULT: IV NS 250 mL bolus if SBP < 100 mmHg with hypotensive symptoms and no signs of pulmonary edema PEDIATRIC: IV NS 20 mL/kg bolus if SBP < (70 + 2x age in years) mmHg with hypotensive symptoms and no signs of pulmonary edema General
If you suspect a patient may have been a victim of sexual assault, request RUPD to respond.

Refer the patient to the SAFE Oﬃce (713-348-3311). The navigators will assist the patient in accessing multiple resources on campus. Rice University partners with Texas Forensic Nurse Examiners to provide a forensic exam on campus in Student Health Services at no cost 24/7.

For students who would like to have a forensic exam performed, there are two oﬀ-campus options available: Memorial Hermann and Ben Taub. If the patient is under the age of 18, the patient should be evaluated at Texas Children’s Hospital. If the student wants to go to the hospital, RUPD can provide a courtesy escort. A SAFE Oﬃce navigator is available to accompany the student to the hospital if desired. Be sure to oﬀer this service to the patient. Please note that forensic exams are also available to students who experienced domestic/dating violence.

To access these services after hours, call 713-348-3311 and ask to speak with the Director of the SAFE Oﬃce. Share that it is an emergency. The answering service will connect with the Oﬃce. Splinting Rice University Emergency Medical Services Clinical Guidelines Criteria

For any trauma incident involving an extremity joint or long bone, the wrist, elbow, shoulder, ankle, knee, etc. whether it was a sporting incident, MVC, or fall, splinting should be considered to stabilize the injury and provide pain relief to the patient. Treatment EMT General supportive care Obtain vitals (apply cardiac monitor) Assist patient to the position of most comfort Joint or Long Bone Injury: Assess for distal pulse, motor, and sensation in all extremities Manually stabilize the bone and surrounding joints Splint above and below the site of injury without compromising any joints to immobilize the injury Reassess for distal pulse, motor, and sensation after splinting ‌Consider application of a cold pack Consider applying a traction splint for a suspected femur fracture General
REMS currently carries SAM splints, padded board splints, cardboard splints, and ACE bandages.
Here is a brief SAM splint guide: Trauma and Hypovolemic Shock Supportive Care Rice University Emergency Medical Services Clinical Guidelines Treatment Priorities

Consider Supraglottic Airway if indicated and only if BVM ventilations are ineffective. ‌Equipment & Procedure Guidelines
Automated External Deﬁbrillation (AED): Adult and Pediatric
Rice University Emergency Medical Services Clinical Guidelines

Adult and pediatric patients that are unconscious, unresponsive, apneic or agonally breathing and pulseless. No contraindications for use. Treatment EMT compatible with LP15 and must be replaced with LP15 pads. Check for consciousness, airway patency, breathing, pulse (CABC) If determined that patient meets all qualiﬁcations for use of AED, turn on AED. Apply AED deﬁbrillation pads. Follow illustrations on deﬁbrillation pads for correct pad placement. Avoid overlapping pads over one another. Avoid placing pads over implanted pacemakers and/or deﬁbrillators. Pediatric AEDs are NOT indicated in patients under 1 years old, utilize manual deﬁbrillation with the LifePak 15 ‌If the patient is between 1 and 8 years old or under 25 kg, use the Infant/Child deﬁbrillation pads If Infant/Child deﬁbrillation pads ae not available, place the Adult deﬁbrillation pads on the posterior and anterior chest. Follow AED visual and voice prompts in conjunction with chest compressions. Utilize the appropriate protocol for the resuscitation of cardiac arrest patients Minimize pauses in chest compressions Consider possible reversible causes of cardiac arrest and treat where appropriate Hypoxia: adequate oxygenation and ventilation with 100% oxygen Acidosis: adequate oxygenation and ventilation with 100% oxygen Trauma: Rapid transport to a trauma center If a Lifepak 15 becomes available and will be used for deﬁbrillation: Adult Lifepak CR2 and CR+ AED pads are compatible with the LP15 monitor. Leave the LP CR2 / CR+ pads on the patient and start deﬁbrillation using LP15. Adult and pediatric pads from Philips and Cardiac Science AEDs are NOT Daily Check Procedures

When checking off the AED at the start of a shift or an event, the following should be checked: One set of adult pads (not expired) Device powers on when opened and voice prompts can be heard. Battery indicator flashes green General

In this setting, the most important thing is to conﬁrm that the patient is unresponsive, unconscious, not breathing normally, and pulseless. If uncertain of any of these qualities, perform a sternal rub to determine responsiveness and consciousness.

In an emergency resuscitation setting that required the use of an AED, do not interrupt or pause chest compressions unless absolutely necessary. For example, continue to provide chest compressions while another operator is applying deﬁbrillation pads, powering on the monitor, selecting appropriate energy and charging the device. HOWEVER: Do NOT continue to provide chest compressions when the AED is discharging or deﬁbrillating.

‌Cardiac Monitor Operation: Lifepak 15 (LP15)
Rice University Emergency Medical Services Clinical Guidelines
Vitals monitoring including EtCO2, SpCO, SpMet, 3-Lead EKG, 12-Lead EKG and defibrillation
Orientation

AED usage Turn on LP15 Retrieve Defibrillation Pads from the right side zippered pocket Connect pads to the therapy cable Attach pads to patient Press Analyze, LP15 will enter automatic mode Follow prompts To cancel at any time, press the speed dial During compression times, pressing the CPR button will silence the metronome Pressing the Energy Select buttons will convert the monitor into manual operation mode (for ALS providers only) Note: Options is not available in AED mode

Manual Defibrillation Turn on the LP15 Attach pads as done with AED Press Energy Select and choose desired energy level Press Charge Ensure all personnel are clear of the patient Confirm EKG rhythm requires defibrillation Confirm available energy To disarm, press the speed dial Press the Shock button (shaped like a lightning bolt) Resume compressions To change metronome settings press CPR Select desired setting (Adult/Youth, Airway/No Airway, Stop Metronome)

Routine Vitals Monitoring Turn on LP15 Attach SpO2 monitor to finger, SpO2 will appear on Channel 2 Attach BP cuff to arm, press NIBP Continue to monitor vitals, press NIBP as desired to get blood pressure readings See “General” to print vitals

EtCO2 Monitoring Turn on LP15 Lift EtCO2 protective cap on monitor Plug in orange “butterfly” to receiver Push in gently Twist clockwise until resistance is felt Allow LP15 to zero itself Attach probe/cannula/rebreather to patient or tube Results should display on Channel 3, can press Print to view

SpCO and SpMET Monitoring Turn on LP15 Unplug “red” SpO2 cable Retrieve “rainbow” SpCO cable from rear lower compartment Plug in “rainbow” cable To get results: Press Print and get value on top banner. If dashed lines appear, try again, or Use the speed-dial to select SpO2 on the left side Select Parameter Select SpCO Press Home Value will appear for ten seconds

3-Lead EKG Turn on LP15 Retrieve electrodes from right-most pocket Attach electrodes to sensors, then to patient LA – Left Arm RA – Right Arm LL – Left Leg RL – Right Leg Place medially, proximal to the most distal major joint (ankle, wrist) Advise patient to remain still and uncross legs if crossed EKG will appear on Channel 1 To generate a rhythm strip, press Print to begin printing, press again to end

12-Lead EKG Turn on LP15 Attach 3-Lead EKG (shown above) Retrieve 12-Lead extension from left-most pocket Plug in extension to 3-Lead splitter Attach electrodes to sensors, then to patient Advise pt. to remain still Press 12-Lead Use speed-dial to select age and gender EKG will print, consider second attempt if patient movement created substantial noise Repeat as necessary Note: EKG’s can only be interpreted by EMT-P or higher. Computer readings are not a substitute for an accurate diagnosis.

To print vitals, options: If LP15 is still on from the same patient Press Code Summary, note that this will print rhythm strips as well if they had been previously generated, or Press Options Select Print Select Report Select one of the following Code Summary (all events including waveforms) Trend Summary (trend graphs for various vital signs) Vital Signs (just a history of the vitals with times) 12 Lead (all 12-Lead EKG’s that were taken) If LP15 has been turned off since the last patient Turn on LP15 Press Options Select Archives Select Yes when prompted to enter patient archives Select Print Select Patient Navigate to correct patient, they are in chronological order Select Report Select options as done above Turn off LP15

To change view options For Channel 1 Press Lead Use speed-dial to select desired lead Press Size Use speed-dial to select desired size For other channels Use speed-dial to select desired channel Use speed-dial to select desired lead/trend/waveform and size Press the Home icon to return
To record events Press Events Use the speed-dial to select desired event Events will record in the code summary

To change the battery Go to the bottom compartment in the rear of the device Open the Flap Remove the yellow Velcro strip Lift up the compartment Press the gray button to see current battery level Replace batteries as needed

To change EKG paper roll Go to the printer compartment below the screen Lift the printer door latch to release the door Pull out the door Remove the paper, including the empty spool if present Insert a new paper roll, making sure the end of the paper extends out of the printer door Close the printer door and ensure it clicks
More information on the LifePak 15, including a full instruction manual, is available at: https://www.stryker.com/us/en/emergency-care/products/lifepak-15.htmlphysiocontrol.com
Cardiac Pacing
Rice University Emergency Medical Services Clinical Guidelines
Symptomatic 2nd Degree AV Block Type II
Symptomatic 3rd Degree AV Block
Symptomatic Bradycardia in Acute Coronary Syndrome in preference to atropine use
Symptomatic Bradycardia unresponsive to non-electrical interventions
Symptomatic Bradycardia in pediatric patients when approved by medical control Contraindications

Asymptomatic Bradycardia Procedure (Lifepak 15) Maintain standard ECG monitoring Apply Quik-Combo pads at chest wall locations illustrated on pads. Dry severe diaphoresis and remove excessive chest hair prior to placement. Connect Quick-Combo pads to Lifepak 15. Advise patient of impending therapy. ‌Power on the pacing function by pressing the PACER button. Ensure triangular “sense” markers are above each QRS complex. Ensure proper connection if they do not appear. If “sense” markers are present for only some QRS complexes, adjust ECG size or select an alternate monitoring lead to achieve proper tracking. Set pacing rate at 60 paces per minute using either the RATE switch or the SPEED DIAL. Set pacing current at minimum level achieving both electrical AND mechanical capture. Deliver electrical pacing current using either the CURRENT switch or the SPEED DIAL. Do not use the pause button unless directed by medical control. Holding the pause button will decrease pacing rate by 25% while it is depressed. If pacing therapy termination is required, power off the pacing function by pressing the PACER button. Considerations If ventricular fibrillation or pulseless ventricular tachycardia occurs, pressing the yellow CHARGE button will automatically stop pacing. Proceed with defibrillation. If monitoring leads become detached, pacing continues but in non- demand mode. During this mode, the patient will receive pacemaker activity at the set rate regardless of any intrinsic beats the patient may have. Reattach the monitoring leads to reestablish demand pacing. If the Quik-Combo pads get detached at any time, an alarm will sound. During this disconnection, the pacing function will resume but current will be set automatically at 0 mA. Current will remain at 0 mA until pads are reconnected and the current is manually increased back to its original level. Electrical capture is demonstrated by a QRS complex after each pacer spike followed by a distinct, broad T-wave. Mechanical capture is demonstrated by a palpable pulse after each pacer spike. Ensure that both electrical capture and mechanical capture are achieved. Pacing Pads should ideally be placed on the anterior and posterior chest. Synchronized Cardioversion Rice University Emergency Medical Services Clinical Guidelines Criteria
Unstable, symptomatic tachycardia: ADULT: HR > 150 bpm PEDIATRIC: HR > 180 bpm AND afebrile
AND hemodynamic compromise: ADULT: SBP < 100 mmHg PEDIATRIC: SBP < (70 + 2x age in years) mmHg Contraindications
Stable tachycardia
Normal sinus rhythm
Bradycardia

Ventricular fibrillation/pulseless ventricular tachycardia Procedure (Lifepak 15) Power ON (figure 1) ‌Attach patient ECG cable and ECG electrodes. Select lead with the greatest QRS complex amplitude positive or negative deflection (figure 2). Press SYNC. The SYNC mode message appears in the message area when SYNC is active (figure 3). Observe the ECG rhythm. Confirm that a triangle marker appears near the middle of each QRS complex (figure 4). If the markers do not appear or are displayed in the wrong location (for example, on the T wave) adjust the ECG size or select another lead. Connect the therapy electrodes to the therapy cable and confirm cable connection to the monitor. Prepare the patient’s skin and apply therapy electrodes to the patient in the anterior-lateral position (figure 6). Press ENERGY SELECT or rotate the SPEED DIAL to select the desired energy (figure 7). Begin at 100J energy. If unstable tachydysrthymia persists, repeat synchronized cardioversion at escalating energy settings of 200J, 300J, 360J. For pediatric synchronized cardioversion, consult medical command for treatment plan and energy settings. Press CHARGE. While the monitor is charging a charging bar appears and a ramping tone sounds, indicating the charging energy level. When the monitor is fully charged, the screen displays the available energy (figure 8). Make certain that all personnel stand clear of the patient, bed, and any equipment connected to the patient. Confirm ECG rhythm. Confirm available energy. Prior to delivering synchronized cardioversion, it is essential to ensure that the SYNC mode message continues to appear. Failure to deliver a “synchronized” cardioversion in this setting could cause ventricular fibrillation arrest in the patient (figure 9). Press and hold the SHOCK button on the monitor until the energy delivered message appears on the screen (figure 10). NOTE: to disarm (cancel the charge), press the SPEED DIAL. The energy disarms automatically if shock buttons are not pressed within 60 seconds, or if the energy selection changes after charging begins. Observe patient and ECG rhythm. Repeat procedures starting from step 4 if necessary.
Medication Administration
Rice University Emergency Medical Services Clinical Guidelines
Ensure the five “rights”
Right patient
Right route
Right dose
Right time
Right medication
If any of these is not correct, do not continue with medication administration.
Procedure and Clearances
Intravenous (IV) and Intraosseous (IO)
AEMT / Paramedic
Assure IV/IO is patent
Cleanse access port
Eject any air from syringe
‌Pinch IV/IO line above the medication port
Inject medication per specification by protocol
Open flow to allow 10-20 mL flush
Intramuscular (IM) and Subcutaneous (SQ)
AEMT / Paramedic
Use 1.0 – 1.5 inch, 21 – 25 gauge needle
Select injection site
Cleanse injection site
Eject air from syringe
If IM, stretch skin over injection site and insert needle at 90o angle. Aspirate. If no blood, inject medication and immediately sharps needle.
If SQ, pinch skin to form a fold and insert needle at 45o angle into the subcutaneous fatty tissue. Aspirate. If no blood, inject medication and immediately sharps needle.
Put bandage over injection site.
Intranasal (IN)
AEMT / Paramedic
Place nasal atomizer onto syringe
Eject air from syringe
Place atomizer tip approximately 1.5 cm into nostril
Briskly compress the syringe plunger to force liquid into a spray directed into the nasal cavity
Sublingual (SL) and Oral (PO)
EMT / AEMT / Paramedic
Instruct, assist, or place tablet or spray under the tongue (SL) or into the mouth (PO)
Medicated Fluid Infusion
Assure patent IV/IO line
Cleanse access port
Flush any air from medicated fluid bag infusion set
Unless simultaneously giving an IV fluid bolus, close IV line above the medication port

Infuse medication per protocol Venous Access: Intravenous Rice University Emergency Medical Services Clinical Guidelines AEMT / Paramedic Criteria Vascular access for intravenous administration of crystalloid fluids in hypotension and/or volume insufficiency Vascular access for intravenous administration of medications for a multitude of medicinally indicated effects Vascular access in a patient with an increased potential for needing either of the above indications Contraindications None absolutely, though despite aseptic technique and using sterile angiocatheters, there is always a risk of introducing infection when the skin integrity is violated. Do not establish IV access unless directed by applicable treatment protocol(s) or the patient meets one of the indications above. Venous sites distal to a fracture ‌Venous sites underlying cellulitis/abscess Venous sites on same extremity with an AV fistula in an ESRD patient Venous sites on upper extremities of patients with axillary node removal (post breast cancer)
Apply IV tourniquet proximal to proposed vascular access site.
Clean insertion site with ChloraPrep®, Betadine®, or alcohol prep.
Stabilize vein in place by applying gentle traction on vein distal to point of entry.
Puncture the skin with the bevel of the needle upward about 0.5 - 1 cm from the vein and enter the vein from the side or from above.
Note blood return and advance the catheter over the needle.
Remove needle and connect IV line. Note: venous blood for laboratory work may be drawn with syringe before connecting IV line.
Release IV tourniquet.
Open IV tubing clamp full to check flow and placement, then slow rate to TKO or as indicated by applicable treatment protocol.
Secure catheter and tubing with tape or commercial device in a manner that reduces traction upon the catheter.
Recheck IV patency periodically to minimize occurrence of unrecognized fluid/medication extravasation.
External Jugular Vein – for peripheral venous access in a patient in extremis only.
Anatomical landmarks, including the vein, must be visible – no “blind” sticks. Avoid multiple attempts and avoid attempts on both sides – use IO access prn.

Position the patient supine, head down (this may not be necessary or desirable if congestive heart failure or respiratory distress present). Turn patient's head to opposite side from procedure. (Maintain cervical spine alignment if cervical spinal injury suspected; do not attempt external jugular vein cannulation in suspected cervical spine injury patients.)
Expose vein by having patient bear down if possible, and "tourniquet" vein with finger pressure just above clavicle.
Clean insertion site with ChloraPrep®, Betadine®, or alcohol prep.
Stabilize vein in place by applying gentle traction on vein distal to point of entry.
Align the cannula in the direction of the vein, with the point aimed toward the shoulder on the same side.
Puncture skin over vein first, then puncture vein itself. Use other hand to traction vein near clavicle to prevent rolling.

Proceed as with extremity vein. Do not wrap any tape/retaining device around the circumference of neck to stabilize IV catheter/line. Complications Local: hematoma formation, infection, thrombosis, phlebitis. Systemic: bacteremia/sepsis, catheter fragment embolism. Considerations Antecubital veins are useful access sites for patients in shock, but, if possible, avoid areas near joints. The point between the junction of two veins is more stable and often easier to use. Start distally and, if successive attempts are necessary, make more proximal attempts. The most difficult problem with IV insertion is to know when to try and when to stop trying. If the procedure is not accomplished after two attempts or two minutes, the AEMT or higher licensed EMS professional must consider expediting other care, including transport to the emergency department. Renal dialysis fistulas and surgically implanted ports should not be used for vascular access. Use IO access in critical patient situations otherwise. Saline locks may be utilized in place of crystalloid infusions/IV lines in conditions less likely to require rapid administration of IV fluid. Venous Access: Intraosseous Rice University Emergency Medical Services Clinical Guidelines AEMT / Paramedic Criteria First choice access in cardio/pulmonary arrest (unless IV access can be achieved as timely). Second choice access in dynamic, life-threatening shock or respiratory failure (if IV access cannot be achieved in clinically needed time). Contraindications Inability to locate anatomical landmarks (blind insertion contraindicated). Suspected cellulitis at insertion site. Suspected acute or non-healed fracture proximal to foot in same leg (proximal tibial insertion) or proximal to forearm in same arm (humeral head insertion). Suspected total knee arthroplasty/replacement (proximal tibial insertion). Suspected markedly poor circulation extremity (history of amputation, gangrene, bypass).
‌SAM IO® System

Assemble the following materials. Driver with needle set based on patient size and weight: PINK: 15 mm for 3-39 kg (non-existent to limited overlying adipose tissue) BLUE: 25 mm for ≥ 40 kg (minimal to moderate overlying adipose tissue) YELLOW: 45 mm for ≥ 40 kg (moderate to excessive overlying adipose tissue) ChloraPrep®, Betadine®, or alcohol wipe Extension set (90) Saline flush syringe SAM IO® Stabilizer NeedleVISE® sharps

Locate the insertion site. Proximal tibia site Palpate patella. Palpate tibial tuberosity approximately two finger widths below patella in adults and adolescents, or one finger width below patella in smaller pediatrics. The insertion site is one finger width medial to tibial tuberosity in the tibial plateau.
Clean the insertion site with alcohol wipe, or preferably with ChloraPrep® or equivalent swab.
Prime infusion set, attach the needle assembly to the driver, and remove the safety cap from the needle assembly. Do not touch uncapped, sterile components of the needle assembly.

Access the intraosseous space. Stabilize anatomy near the insertion site with non-dominant hand. Position driver at insertion site with needle at a 90 angle to the surface of the bone. Use the driver to insert the needle through the skin and adipose tissue at the insertion site until you feel the needle tip encounter bone. Ensure that ≥ 5 mm of catheter (at least the first black line on proximal catheter) is visible above the skin before attempting intraosseous insertion. Continuously actuate (repeatedly compress) the driver’s trigger assembly, while applying gentle, steady downward insertion pressure to achieve controlled entry. Use minimal (gentle) steady downward insertion pressure. Allow needle assembly tip rotation to penetrate compact bone. Discontinue trigger actuation when a subtle “give” or “pop” is appreciated, indicating needle assembly entry into the medullary space. Once the bone cortex feels encountered, ensure that ≥ 5 mm of catheter (at least the first black line on proximal catheter). If at least one 5 mm mark line is not visible, a longer needle will be required to achieve usable intraosseous access. Remove the stylet by stabilizing the needle assembly hub while retracting (lifting off) and disconnecting the driver. The stylet will remain attached to the driver. While holding the driver, guide the stylet into the provided NeedleVISE® or appropriate sharps containment device and disconnect the stylet from the driver. Apply sterile SAM IO® Stabilizer carefully over catheter and against skin. Attach primed extension set to catheter hub, firmly secure by twisting clockwise. Do NOT attempt aspiration of blood or marrow via the catheter. Pulling marrow into the catheter may clog the catheter and prevent its use for fluid and/or medication administration. Confirm proper catheter placement using a combination of the following signs: IO catheter rests at a 90 angle and feels firmly in bone when grasping hub.
Blood-tinged marrow oozes spontaneously from hub (may often be absent, yet the catheter is still correctly placed).
Fluid and medication administration is possible without significant resistance and without extravasation.

Flush SAM IO® catheter with 10 mL normal saline. Medication administration is given in the same dosing as with IV administrations. Fluid administration will require the use of a pressure infuser on the IV fluid bag. Due to the increased pressure of the marrow space, IV fluid will not infuse without assistance of the pressure infuser. Inflate pressure infuser until IV fluid is seen infusing with constant flow. Monitor for extravasation and monitor for need to reinflate pressure infuser. Fluid delivery rate may be as high as 1 liter per hour.

In determining the site for IO access, consider knowledge of the anatomy, prior training, and comfort in accessing that particular site, and how IO access at that site may or may not interfere with other care events (e.g., use of the humeral head site for medication administration in cardiac arrest could disrupt the continuity of chest compressions).
Additional information about SAM IO® system: https://www.sammedical.com/blogs/training/sam-io
Complications
Through and through bone penetration avoid by using correct needle and insertion technique
Extravasation avoid by using correct needle and insertion technique monitor ongoing use and stop at early signs of extravasation
Fracture of bone avoid by using correct insertion technique (avoid excessive pressure)
Infection avoid by using aseptic technique and do not insert through suspected cellulitis
Growth plate injury in pediatrics avoid by choosing correct insertion site
Airway Assessment
Rice University Emergency Medical Services Clinical Guidelines
In order to assess a patient’s airway, there are several principles that must be followed in order to adequately determine if any interventions are needed:
Use the least invasive method of airway management appropriate to the patient
Position the airway that provides the most appropriate access Use a head tilt-chin lift for medical patients Use jaw thrust maneuver for trauma patients with suspected C-spine injures / precautions
Only use an airway management method that you are credentialed to perform
Patients may require frequent suctioning in order to keep the airway clear of debris

Monitor the patient continuously in order to ensure that oxygenation and/or ventilations are effective Use supplemental oxygen via nasal cannula (NC), non-rebreather mask (NRB), or bag-valve mask (BVM) as necessary

Remember the following important concepts: ‌Patency: Open and clear the airway by looking for foreign substances, blood, vomitus, or tongue obstruction. Suction, if necessary, to clear the airway and/or consider repositioning the patient’s airway. Ventilation: Determine the volume / amount of air the patient is able to inhale and exhale in a given time. Waveform capnography provides effective real time measurement of ventilation. Oxygenation: Determine the amount of oxygen the patient is able to convey to the circulation for tissue/organ perfusion. Pulse oximetry may be used in this case to help assessment. Rember that pulse oximetry readings are delayed. Important Considerations:

The above guidelines are the approach to typical medical and trauma-related airway problems. They assume the treating EMS professional is skilled in the various procedures appropriate for their scope of practice.
Advanced airway procedures should only be attempted if clinically indicated after less invasive measures fail or are futile to attempt. Individual cases may require modification of these protocols.
Airway management decisions and actions should always be thoroughly documented in the patient care report.

Intoxicated (either by alcohol or drugs), trauma (especially head trauma) or altered mental status patients require careful monitoring of the airway. For these patients, be prepared to perform interventions as symptoms of respiratory distress may have a sudden onset. Airway Suctioning Rice University Emergency Medical Services Clinical Guidelines Indications:
Trauma to the face or upper airway with the potential for, or actual, airway obstruction
Vomitus, food, or other foreign liquid material in the airway
Excess secretions or pulmonary edema ﬂuid in the upper airway
Amniotic ﬂuid in the pharynx of a newborn with obvious obstruction to spontaneous breathing or who require positive-pressure ventilation
Meconium in pharynx of a non-vigorous newborn
Technique:
Open the airway and inspect for visible foreign material For trauma patients, use the jaw thrust method
Turn the patient on their side to facilitate clearance of foreign liquid materials

Remove large or obvious foreign bodies with gloved hands. ‌Sweep ﬁnger ACROSS the posterior pharynx and clear the visible material out of the mouth Do not perform blind ﬁnger sweeps of the airway. This may lodge the obstruction further into the airway
Turn on suction machine

Suction the oropharynx Attach appropriate tip to the suction unit (French catheter vs DuCanto tip) Oxygenate and/or ventilate the patient prior to this procedure, as needed Insert the tip into the oropharynx under direct vision, with a sweeping motion. Do not suction for longer than 10 seconds. Continue intermittent suction interspersed with active oxygenation by mask. Use positive pressure ventilation if needed. If suction becomes clogged, dilute by suctioning water or normal saline to clean the obstructed tubing. If suction clogs repeatedly, use connecting tube alone, or manually remove large debris.
Important Considerations:

In most situations, limit the suction time to no longer than 10 seconds. However, this precaution should NOT be followed when vomitus or other material continues to well up and completely obstruct the airway. In this case, suctioning must be continued until an airway is reestablished, with intermittent oxygenation and ventilation performed to avoid prolonged lack of oxygen.

When possible, have a container of water or normal saline at hand before beginning suctioning as it may require frequent rinsing of the catheter and tubing. Use gauze to remove large material from the end of the catheter. Equipment Notes:

Rice EMS uses the Laerdal Suction Units. These units operate off battery power and should be recharged regularly. To check the battery power, turn on the device. If the battery indicator light (next to the power button) shows yellow, the unit needs to be recharged.
Oxygen Administration
Rice University Emergency Medical Services Clinical Guidelines
Presentation of hypoxia/hypoxemia with symptoms of respiratory distress
Conditions directed by specific protocol
Chronic conditions (COPD, lung disease)
Acute conditions (respiratory arrest, cardiac arrest, acute coronary syndrome, acute onset dyspnea, allergic reaction, multi-systems trauma, AND SpO2 < 95%) Contraindications
SpO2 ≥ 95% if no concern for acute ischemia and infarction
As noted in specific protocols

Gather and prepare all equipment: Don appropriate body substance isolation (gloves and eye protection) Prepare oxygen tank with regulator Select appropriate oxygen administration device (nasal cannula, nebulizer, NRB, BVM)
‌Decide how much oxygen is necessary for patient’s condition.
Instruct/inform patient of how the device functions.
Release any residual oxygen in regulator.
Connect tubing to regulator.
Open the oxygen tank by rotating the valve.
Adjust regulator to desired flow rate.
If using an NRB, be sure to fill the reservoir bag before administering to patient.
Appropriately secure administration device to patient.
Continue to monitor patient and titrate oxygen as necessary.
Non-Rebreather
REMS carries infant, pediatric, and adult non-rebreather masks. Be sure to accurately size the mask for optimal oxygen administration.
Fill the reservoir bag by covering the one-way valve.
Fit the mask comfortably over the patient’s nose and mouth.
The top of the mask should cover the patient’s nose and the bottom should extend over the anterior portion of the chin.
Pinch the nosepiece to fit the contour of the patient’s nose and make sure the one-way valve sits below the patient’s mouth.

Secure the mask around the patient’s head using the green elastic straps. Flow Rates of Different Administration Devices Nasal Cannula: 2 – 6 L/min Nebulizer: 6 – 8 L/min Non-Rebreather Mask: 10 – 15 L/min Bag-Valve Mask: 15 – 20 L/min Considerations Consider all possible causes of respiratory distress. Administration should be directed to achieve oxygen saturation level of 94-98% in patients without chronic pulmonary disorders. Over administration of oxygen has been shown to produce serious adverse outcomes. Do not administer oxygen if SpO2 is greater than 95% on room air with no signs of respiratory distress. Administration of blow-by oxygen via NRB at 10-15 L/min can be achieved by holding the mask near the patient’s nose/mouth. This is a common administration route for pediatric patients who may be averse to having a nasal cannula/mask secured on the face. Consider use of humidified oxygen when using nasal cannula at high flow rates. A BVM connected to 15 L/min of oxygen should be used if the patient is unconscious and unable to breathe, respiratory rate ≤ 8 breaths/minute, or agonal respirations are noted. If the patient is conscious and experiencing profound respiratory distress, consider use of a BVM to give controlled, regular breaths. Be sure to explain procedure to patient and coach him/her to cooperate with the breaths you give, in order to avoid extreme discomfort and exacerbating damage to the lungs. Have the patient breathe with the squeezes of the bag and give oxygen only until chest rise is observed. Oxygen tanks should be replaced when pressure ≤ 500 psi, or some malfunction is detected (air leakage, obstruction to administration). Notify the Operations Lieutenant when switching out an oxygen tank. Bag Valve Mask (BVM) Management Rice University Emergency Medical Services Clinical Guidelines Criteria: Respiratory arrest Inadequate oxygenation or ventilation that is not improved by non-positive pressure methods or immediately obvious that patient will not improve by non-positive pressure methods Technique: Hold the mask using a c/e-clamp formed by one, but preferably, both hands Insert an oropharyngeal and/or nasopharyngeal airway(s) Head-tilt chin lift to place the patient in a sniffing position to open the airway Use the jaw thrust maneuver in suspected spinal cord injuries Place the mask over the mouth and elevate the jaw into the mask, ensuring an adequate seal Consider the Sellick maneuver, if indicated, by putting pressure on the cricoid cartilage to partially occlude the esophagus in the unconscious patient. ‌Do not utilize if ventilations are effective and without onset of gastric distention. Emesis is a distinct possibility after releasing Sellick maneuver. Use high flow, 100% oxygen with BVM ventilations Squeeze the bag slowly and smoothly (over 1 second ventilation periods) delivering adequate ventilation volume to ensure the chest rises (approximately 6 mL/kg of air) and provide adequate exhalation time. Important Considerations: Optimal Bag valve mask ventilations often requires two EMTs Nebulization Therapy Rice University Emergency Medical Services Clinical Guidelines Criteria Dyspnea of uncertain etiology Bronchospasm Acute allergic reaction Reactive Airway Disease (i.e., asthma or COPD) Infectious exacerbation Toxic inhalations
Assemble nebulization device
Explain procedure to the patient
Fill nebulization chamber with medication to be nebulized
Initiate 6 – 8 L/min of oxygen flow with the hand-held nebulization device or via a face mask
Place mouthpiece in patient’s mouth If this is not possible, direct the medication at the patient’s nose/mouth via nebulizer face mask
‌When delivering the treatment, ask the patient to hold their breath for 1 – 2 seconds after inhaling before exhaling
Considerations
This process is commonly used with albuterol. Patients should be continually assessed during albuterol treatment. Treatment should be discontinued if HR increases ≥ 20 bpm.
Supraglottic Airway – Air-Q SP3G
Rice University Emergency Medical Services Clinical Guidelines
Hypoxia and/or hypoventilation refractory to noninvasive airway/respiratory management
Airway protection to reduce aspiration in the setting of sustained altered mental status with a Glasgow Coma Scale Score < 8 Contraindications for use:
Ability to maintain oxygenation and ventilation by less invasive methods, such as BVM
Intact gag reflex
Known esophageal disease
Ingestion of caustic substance (i.e. lye, acids) or extensive airway burns
Tracheotomy or laryngectomy
Suspected foreign body airway obstruction
Procedure:
Prepare the suction device and have it readily available.
Place the patient on SPO2 monitoring and watch SPO2 levels throughout procedure.
Select the correctly sized Air-Q device using ideal body weight (Sizing guide below)
‌Lubricate the external surface of the device
Pre-oxygenate the patient using 100% oxygen via NRB or BVM
Position the head in the “sniffing” position (head tilt chin lift or jaw thrust)
Hold the Air-Q with your dominant hand
Open the mouth and lift the tongue with the non-dominant hand
Insert the Air-Q into the mouth
Apply inward and downward pressure, using the curvature of the Air-Q as a guide. Advance until fixed resistance is felt. Do not force insertion.
The properly positioned Air-Q should have the patient’s teeth between the two black lines.
If needed, inflate the Air-Q using the provided syringe to the volume listed on the packaging.
Attach the BVM with EtCO2 and ventilate.
Assess for chest rise and fall, auscultate breath sounds bilaterally, and maintain continuous EtCO2 monitoring. Remember to document these findings in the patient’s chart.
If ventilation is not accomplished, pull back slightly and re-attempt placement. If needed, repeat steps 9 – 11 and reconfirm Air-Q placement.
Secure the Air-Q with a commercial airway securing device
Ventilate with oxygen at the appropriate rate.
If the Air-Q is removed, suction must be available. Do not discard the Air-Q until the airway is secured.

Consider Gastric Tube placement (OG Tube) through the gastric side ports. Sizing Guide: Size Device Color IBW by Height IBW in kg IBW in lbs Max OG Tube 1 Blue - 4 – 7 kg 9 – 15 lbs 8 fr 1.5 Green - 8 – 16 kg 16 – 36 lbs 8 fr 2 Orange - 17 – 30 kg 37 – 66 lbs 10 fr 3 Yellow 4’6 – 5’6 30 – 60 kg 67 – 132 lbs 14 fr 4 Red 5’7 – 6’2 60 – 80 kg 133 – 175 lbs 16 fr 5 Purple > 6’3 > 80 kg > 176 lbs 18 fr IBW = Ideal Body Weight Precautions: Utilize BVM ventilation if Air-Q SP3G is unsuccessful after two attempts Never force the tube during insertion as it may cause trauma to airway or esophagus Ensure you assess and document placement verification of Air-Q SP3G and note any complications. Rice University Emergency Medical Services Clinical Guidelines
Indications
Medical and Trauma General Assessment
Acute Dyspnea (Uncertain etiology, Asthma, COPD, or CHF)

Any patient complaining of dyspnea and self-administers an inhaler on scene, or who receives medication from a Rice EMS provider, MUST have an assessment of End-Tidal CO2 measurement and waveform capnography (unless the equipment is not available) before refusing transport. Contraindications
None Technique:

Connect the End-Tidal CO2 Filter line tubing by turning clockwise until it fits securely. This is evidenced by the wings in a horizontal position and the message “CO2 Initializing” appearing on the LifePak screen. Normal EtCO2 range is 35 – 45 mmHg Critical Information:

When an End-Tidal CO2 measurement or waveform is not detected, or is suddenly lost during monitoring, providers should assess for the following three situations: Equipment Failure Possible causes: Disconnected or malfunctioning bag valve or ventilator or severed EtCO2 filter line EtCO2 failure of the LifePak 15 is incredibly rare, but it would be indicated by 3 Xs listed where the CO2 measurement should be. The secondary LifePak 15 should be requested and used. Loss of the Airway Possible Causes: Apnea, Placement or migration of the Endotracheal tube into the Esophagus. Circulatory Collapse Possible causes: Cardiac Arrest, massive pulmonary embolism, severe blood loss (exsanguination) General Overview of Capnography Interpretation Phase I: Respiratory Baseline
Value should be 0 mmHg, reflects inspired gas which normally does not contain carbon dioxide Phase II: Expiratory Upstroke
Increase in CO2 is caused by oxygen and carbon dioxide diffusing within the alveoli, exhalation begins Phase III: Alveolar Plateau
Exhalation of alveolar gases which are made up of mostly carbon dioxide
EtCO2 is measured at the highest point (the β angle) Phase O: Inspiratory Downstroke
Start of inhalation, carbon dioxide levels decrease as oxygen enters into the lungs
Normal EtCO2 range is 35 – 45 mmHg
‌Blood Glucose Analysis
Rice University Emergency Medical Services Clinical Guidelines
Blood glucose analysis should be considered for any patient with: Altered mental status Suspected stroke Syncope or near syncope Suspected drug or alcohol overdose
Any ill infant should have a blood glucose analysis
Assemble equipment. Insert single use test strip into meter with clear blood slot facing away from meter. Meter will turn on.

When blood drop symbol flashes, obtain drop of blood from fingertip. Choose whichever finger is least calloused. Apply pressure to finger to help increase blood flow. Clean fingertip with alcohol pad without contaminating area. Allow area to dry.

Hold finger and firmly place new, sterile lancet off center on fingertip. Firmly press lancet to puncture fingertip. Wipe first drop of blood with sterile gauze and touch next drop of blood to clear window of test strip.
When flash is observed on test strip, enough blood has been added to test strip. Record value on glucometer and properly dispose of all contaminated supplies.
If BGL analysis is < 60 mg/dL with indicated symptoms, proceed with hypoglycemic protocol outlined in Altered Mental Status.
Equipment Notes

REMS currently uses the Assure® Prism glucometers. The chip-like end (top) of the test strip should be inserted into the glucometer, in the same orientation shown below. The narrowed end (bottom) of the test strip should be used for blood drop collection. The clear chamber near the blood drop collection end must be filled with blood to have a usable glucometer reading. If the display reads error, a new strip must be used, and the analysis should be reattempted.
